world his rays.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Smintheus! sprung from fair Latona\xe2\x80\x99s line,47\r\nThou guardian power of Cilla the divine,48\r\nThou source of light! whom Tenedos adores,\r\nAnd whose bright presence gilds thy Chrysa\xe2\x80\x99s shores.\r\nIf e\xe2\x80\x99er with wreaths I hung thy sacred fane,49\r\nOr fed the flames with fat of oxen slain;\r\nGod of the silver bow! thy shafts employ,\r\nAvenge thy servant, and the Greeks destroy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus Chryses pray\xe2\x80\x99d.\xe2\x80\x94the favouring power attends,\r\nAnd from Olympus\xe2\x80\x99 lofty tops descends.\r\nBent was his bow, the Grecian hearts to wound;50\r\nFierce as he moved, his silver shafts resound.\r\nBreathing revenge, a sudden night he spread,\r\nAnd gloomy darkness roll\xe2\x80\x99d about his head.\r\nThe fleet in view, he twang\xe2\x80\x99d his deadly bow,\r\nAnd hissing fly the feather\xe2\x80\x99d fates below.\r\nOn mules and dogs the infection first began;51\r\nAnd last, the vengeful arrows fix\xe2\x80\x99d in man.\r\nFor nine long nights, through all the dusky air,\r\nThe pyres, thick-flaming, shot a dismal glare.\r\nBut ere the tenth revolving day was run,\r\nInspired by Juno, Thetis\xe2\x80\x99 godlike son\r\nConvened to council all the Grecian train;\r\nFor much the goddess mourn\xe2\x80\x99d her heroes slain.52\r\nThe assembly seated, rising o\xe2\x80\x99er the rest,\r\nAchilles thus the king of men address\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy leave we not the fatal Trojan shore,\r\nAnd measure back the seas we cross\xe2\x80\x99d before?\r\nThe plague destroying whom the sword would spare,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis time to save the few remains of war.\r\nBut let some prophet, or some sacred sage,\r\nExplore the cause of great Apollo\xe2\x80\x99s rage;\r\nOr learn the wasteful vengeance to remove\r\nBy mystic dreams, for dreams descend from Jove.53\r\nIf broken vows this heavy curse have laid,\r\nLet altars smoke, and hecatombs be paid.\r\nSo Heaven, atoned, shall dying Greece restore,\r\nAnd Phoebus dart his burning shafts no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said, and sat: when Chalcas thus replied;\r\nChalcas the wise, the Grecian priest and guide,\r\nThat sacred seer, whose comprehensive view,\r\nThe past, the present, and the future knew:\r\nUprising slow, the venerable sage\r\nThus spoke the prudence and the fears of age:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeloved of Jove, Achilles! would\xe2\x80\x99st thou know\r\nWhy angry Phoebus bends his fatal bow?\r\nFirst give thy faith, and plight a prince\xe2\x80\x99s word\r\nOf sure protection, by thy power and sword:\r\nFor I must speak what wisdom would conceal,\r\nAnd truths, invidious to the great, reveal,\r\nBold is the task, when subjects, grown too wise,\r\nInstruct a monarch where his error lies;\r\nFor though we deem the short-lived fury past,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis sure the mighty will revenge at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nTo whom Pelides:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFrom thy inmost soul\r\nSpeak what thou know\xe2\x80\x99st, and speak without control.\r\nE\xe2\x80\x99en by that god I swear who rules the day,\r\nTo whom thy hands the vows of Greece convey.\r\nAnd whose bless\xe2\x80\x99d oracles thy lips declare;\r\nLong as Achilles breathes this vital air,\r\nNo daring Greek, of all the numerous band,\r\nAgainst his priest shall lift an impious hand;\r\nNot e\xe2\x80\x99en the chief by whom our hosts are led,\r\nThe king of kings, shall touch that sacred head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEncouraged thus, the blameless man replies:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor vows unpaid, nor slighted sacrifice,\r\nBut he, our chief, provoked the raging pest,\r\nApollo\xe2\x80\x99s vengeance for his injured priest.\r\nNor will the god\xe2\x80\x99s awaken\xe2\x80\x99d fury cease,\r\nBut plagues shall spread, and funeral fires increase,\r\nTill the great king, without a ransom paid,\r\nTo her own Chrysa send the black-eyed maid.54\r\nPerhaps, with added sacrifice and prayer,\r\nThe priest may pardon, and the god may spare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe prophet spoke: when with a gloomy frown\r\nThe monarch started from his shining throne;\r\nBlack choler fill\xe2\x80\x99d his breast that boil\xe2\x80\x99d with ire,\r\nAnd from his eye-balls flash\xe2\x80\x99d the living fire:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAugur accursed! denouncing mischief still,\r\nProphet of plagues, for ever boding ill!\r\nStill must that tongue some wounding message bring,\r\nAnd still thy priestly pride provoke thy king?\r\nFor this are Phoebus\xe2\x80\x99 oracles explored,\r\nTo teach the Greeks to murmur at their lord?\r\nFor this with falsehood is my honour stain\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nIs heaven offended, and a priest profaned;\r\nBecause my prize, my beauteous maid, I hold,\r\nAnd heavenly charms prefer to proffer\xe2\x80\x99d gold?\r\nA maid, unmatch\xe2\x80\x99d in manners as in face,\r\nSkill\xe2\x80\x99d in each art, and crown\xe2\x80\x99d with every grace;\r\nNot half so dear were Clytaemnestra\xe2\x80\x99s charms,\r\nWhen first her blooming beauties bless\xe2\x80\x99d my arms.\r\nYet, if the gods demand her, let her sail;\r\nOur cares are only for the public weal:\r\nLet me be deem\xe2\x80\x99d the hateful cause of all,\r\nAnd suffer, rather than my people fall.\r\nThe prize, the beauteous prize, I will resign,\r\nSo dearly valued, and so justly mine.\r\nBut since for common good I yield the fair,\r\nMy private loss let grateful Greece repair;\r\nNor unrewarded let your prince complain,\r\nThat he alone has fought and bled in vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInsatiate king (Achilles thus replies),\r\nFond of the power, but fonder of the prize!\r\nWould\xe2\x80\x99st thou the Greeks their lawful prey should yield,\r\nThe due reward of many a well-fought field?\r\n\r\nThe spoils of cities razed and warriors slain,\r\nWe share with justice, as with toil we gain;\r\nBut to resume whate\xe2\x80\x99er thy avarice craves\r\n(That trick of tyrants) may be borne by slaves.\r\nYet if our chief for plunder only fight,\r\nThe spoils of Ilion shall thy loss requite,\r\nWhene\xe2\x80\x99er, by Jove\xe2\x80\x99s decree, our conquering powers\r\nShall humble to the dust her lofty towers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen thus the king: \xe2\x80\x9cShall I my prize resign\r\nWith tame content, and thou possess\xe2\x80\x99d of thine?\r\nGreat as thou art, and like a god in fight,\r\nThink not to rob me of a soldier\xe2\x80\x99s right.\r\nAt thy demand shall I restore the maid?\r\nFirst let the just equivalent be paid;\r\nSuch as a king might ask; and let it be\r\nA treasure worthy her, and worthy me.\r\nOr grant me this, or with a monarch\xe2\x80\x99s claim\r\nThis hand shall seize some other captive dame.\r\nThe mighty Ajax shall his prize resign;55\r\nUlysses\xe2\x80\x99 spoils, or even thy own, be mine.\r\nThe man who suffers, loudly may complain;\r\nAnd rage he may, but he shall rage in vain.\r\nBut this when time requires.\xe2\x80\x94It now remains\r\nWe launch a bark to plough the watery plains,\r\nAnd waft the sacrifice to Chrysa\xe2\x80\x99s shores,\r\nWith chosen pilots, and with labouring oars.\r\nSoon shall the fair the sable ship ascend,\r\nAnd some deputed prince the charge attend:\r\nThis Creta\xe2\x80\x99s king, or Ajax shall fulfil,\r\nOr wise Ulysses see perform\xe2\x80\x99d our will;\r\nOr, if our royal pleasure shall ordain,\r\nAchilles\xe2\x80\x99 self conduct her o\xe2\x80\x99er the main;\r\nLet fierce Achilles, dreadful in his rage,\r\nThe god propitiate, and the pest assuage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration: MARS.]\r\n\r\nAt this, Pelides, frowning stern, replied:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO tyrant, arm\xe2\x80\x99d with insolence and pride!\r\nInglorious slave to interest, ever join\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nWith fraud, unworthy of a royal mind!\r\nWhat generous Greek, obedient to thy word,\r\nShall form an ambush, or shall lift the sword?\r\nWhat cause have I to war at thy decree?\r\nThe distant Trojans never injured me;\r\nTo Phthia\xe2\x80\x99s realms no hostile troops they led:\r\nSafe in her vales my warlike coursers fed;\r\nFar hence removed, the hoarse-resounding main,\r\nAnd walls of rocks, secure my native reign,\r\nWhose fruitful soil luxuriant harvests grace,\r\nRich in her fruits, and in her martial race.\r\nHither we sail\xe2\x80\x99d, a voluntary throng,\r\nTo avenge a private, not a public wrong:\r\nWhat else to Troy the assembled nations draws,\r\nBut thine, ungrateful, and thy brother\xe2\x80\x99s cause?\r\nIs this the pay our blood and toils deserve;\r\nDisgraced and injured by the man we serve?\r\nAnd darest thou threat to snatch my prize away,\r\nDue to the deeds of many a dreadful day?\r\nA prize as small, O tyrant! match\xe2\x80\x99d with thine,\r\nAs thy own actions if compared to mine.\r\nThine in each conquest is the wealthy prey,\r\nThough mine the sweat and danger of the day.\r\nSome trivial present to my ships I bear:\r\nOr barren praises pay the wounds of war.\r\nBut know, proud monarch, I\xe2\x80\x99m thy slave no more;\r\nMy fleet shall waft me to Thessalia\xe2\x80\x99s shore:\r\nLeft by Achilles on the Trojan plain,\r\nWhat spoils, what conquests, shall Atrides gain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this the king: \xe2\x80\x9cFly, mighty warrior! fly;\r\nThy aid we need not, and thy threats defy.\r\nThere want not chiefs in such a cause to fight,\r\nAnd Jove himself shall guard a monarch\xe2\x80\x99s right.\r\nOf all the kings (the god\xe2\x80\x99s distinguish\xe2\x80\x99d care)\r\nTo power superior none such hatred bear:\r\nStrife and debate thy restless soul employ,\r\nAnd wars and horrors are thy savage joy,\r\nIf thou hast strength, \xe2\x80\x99twas Heaven that strength bestow\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nFor know, vain man! thy valour is from God.\r\nHaste, launch thy vessels, fly with speed away;\r\nRule thy own realms with arbitrary sway;\r\nI heed thee not, but prize at equal rate\r\nThy short-lived friendship, and thy groundless hate.\r\nGo, threat thy earth-born Myrmidons:\xe2\x80\x94but here56\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis mine to threaten, prince, and thine to fear.\r\nKnow, if the god the beauteous dame demand,\r\nMy bark shall waft her to her native land;\r\nBut then prepare, imperious prince! prepare,\r\nFierce as thou art, to yield thy captive fair:\r\nEven in thy tent I\xe2\x80\x99ll seize the blooming prize,\r\nThy loved Briseis with the radiant eyes.\r\nHence shalt thou prove my might, and curse the hour\r\nThou stood\xe2\x80\x99st a rival of imperial power;\r\nAnd hence, to all our hosts it shall be known,\r\nThat kings are subject to the gods alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAchilles heard, with grief and rage oppress\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nHis heart swell\xe2\x80\x99d high, and labour\xe2\x80\x99d in his breast;\r\nDistracting thoughts by turns his bosom ruled;\r\nNow fired by wrath, and now by reason cool\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\nThat prompts his hand to draw the deadly sword,\r\nForce through the Greeks, and pierce their haughty lord;\r\nThis whispers soft his vengeance to control,\r\nAnd calm the rising tempest of his soul.\r\nJust as in anguish of suspense he stay\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nWhile half unsheathed appear\xe2\x80\x99d the glittering blade,57\r\nMinerva swift descended from above,\r\nSent by the sister and the wife of Jove\r\n(For both the princes claim\xe2\x80\x99d her equal care);\r\nBehind she stood, and by the golden hair\r\nAchilles seized; to him alone confess\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nA sable cloud conceal\xe2\x80\x99d her from the rest.\r\nHe sees, and sudden to the goddess cries,\r\nKnown by the flames that sparkle from her eyes:\r\n\r\n[Illustration: MINERVA REPRESSING THE FURY OF ACHILLES.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDescends Minerva, in her guardian care,\r\nA heavenly witness of the wrongs I bear\r\nFrom Atreus\xe2\x80\x99 son?\xe2\x80\x94Then let those eyes that view\r\nThe daring crime, behold the vengeance too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForbear (the progeny of Jove replies)\r\nTo calm thy fury I forsake the skies:\r\nLet great Achilles, to the gods resign\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nTo reason yield the empire o\xe2\x80\x99er his mind.\r\nBy awful Juno this command is given;\r\nThe king and you are both the care of heaven.\r\nThe force of keen reproaches let him feel;\r\nBut sheathe, obedient, thy revenging steel.\r\nFor I pronounce (and trust a heavenly power)\r\nThy injured honour has its fated hour,\r\nWhen the proud monarch shall thy arms implore,\r\nAnd bribe thy friendship with a boundless store.\r\nThen let revenge no longer bear the sway;\r\nCommand thy passions, and the gods obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo her Pelides:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWith regardful ear,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis just, O goddess! I thy dictates hear.\r\nHard as it is, my vengeance I suppress:\r\nThose who revere the gods the gods will bless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe said, observant of the blue-eyed maid;\r\nThen in the sheath return\xe2\x80\x99d the shining blade.\r\nThe goddess swift to high Olympus flies,\r\nAnd joins the sacred senate of the skies.\r\n\r\nNor yet the rage his boiling breast forsook,\r\nWhich thus redoubling on Atrides broke:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO monster! mix\xe2\x80\x99d of insolence and fear,\r\nThou dog in forehead, but in heart a deer!\r\nWhen wert thou known in ambush\xe2\x80\x99d fights to dare,\r\nOr nobly face the horrid front of war?\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis ours, the chance of fighting fields to try;\r\nThine to look on, and bid the valiant die:\r\nSo much \xe2\x80\x99tis safer through the camp to go,\r\nAnd rob a subject, than despoil a foe.\r\nScourge of thy people, violent and base!\r\nSent in Jove\xe2\x80\x99s anger on a slavish race;\r\nWho, lost to sense of generous freedom past,\r\nAre tamed to wrongs;\xe2\x80\x94or this had been thy last.\r\nNow by this sacred sceptre hear me swear,\r\nWhich never more shall leaves or blossoms bear,\r\nWhich sever\xe2\x80\x99d from the trunk (as I from thee)\r\nOn the bare mountains left its parent tree;\r\nThis sceptre, form\xe2\x80\x99d by temper\xe2\x80\x99d steel to prove\r\nAn ensign of the delegates of Jove,\r\nFrom whom the power of laws and justice springs\r\n(Tremendous oath! inviolate to kings);\r\nBy this I swear:\xe2\x80\x94when bleeding Greece again\r\nShall call Achilles, she shall call in vain.\r\nWhen, flush\xe2\x80\x99d with slaughter, Hector comes to spread\r\nThe purpled shore with mountains of the dead,\r\nThen shall thou mourn the affront thy madness gave,\r\nForced to deplore when impotent to save:\r\nThen rage in bitterness of soul to know\r\nThis act has made the bravest Greek thy foe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe spoke; and furious hurl\xe2\x80\x99d against the ground\r\nHis sceptre starr\xe2\x80\x99d with golden studs around:\r\nThen sternly silent sat. With like disdain\r\nThe raging king return\xe2\x80\x99d his frowns again.\r\n\r\nTo calm their passion with the words of age,\r\nSlow from his seat arose the Pylian sage,\r\nExperienced Nestor, in persuasion skill\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nWords, sweet as honey, from his lips distill\xe2\x80\x99d:58\r\nTwo generations now had pass\xe2\x80\x99d away,\r\nWise by his rules, and happy by his sway;\r\nTwo ages o\xe2\x80\x99er his native realm he reign\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAnd now the example of the third remain\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nAll view\xe2\x80\x99d with awe the venerable man;\r\nWho thus with mild benevolence began:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shame, what woe is this to Greece! what joy\r\nTo Troy\xe2\x80\x99s proud monarch, and the friends of Troy!\r\nThat adverse gods commit to stern debate\r\nThe best, the bravest, of the Grecian state.\r\nYoung as ye are, this youthful heat restrain,\r\nNor think your Nestor\xe2\x80\x99s years and wisdom vain.\r\nA godlike race of heroes once I knew,\r\nSuch as no more these aged eyes shall view!\r\nLives there a chief to match Pirithous\xe2\x80\x99 fame,\r\nDryas the bold, or Ceneus\xe2\x80\x99 deathless name;\r\nTheseus, endued with more than mortal might,\r\nOr Polyphemus, like the gods in fight?\r\nWith these of old, to toils of battle bred,\r\nIn early youth my hardy days I led;\r\nFired with the thirst which virtuous envy breeds,\r\nAnd smit with love of honourable deeds,\r\nStrongest of men, they pierced the mountain boar,\r\nRanged the wild deserts red with monsters\xe2\x80\x99 gore,\r\nAnd from their hills the shaggy Centaurs tore:\r\nYet these with soft persuasive arts I sway\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nWhen Nestor spoke, they listen\xe2\x80\x99d and obey\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nIf in my youth, even these esteem\xe2\x80\x99d me wise;\r\nDo you, young warriors, hear my age advise.\r\nAtrides, seize not on the beauteous slave;\r\nThat prize the Greeks by common suffrage gave:\r\nNor thou, Achilles, treat our prince with pride;\r\nLet kings be just, and sovereign power preside.\r\nThee, the first honours of the war adorn,\r\nLike gods in strength, and of a goddess born;\r\nHim, awful majesty exalts above\r\nThe powers of earth, and sceptred sons of Jove.\r\nLet both unite with well-consenting mind,\r\nSo shall authority with strength be join\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nLeave me, O king! to calm Achilles\xe2\x80\x99 rage;\r\nRule thou thyself, as more advanced in age.\r\nForbid it, gods! Achilles should be lost,\r\nThe pride of Greece, and bulwark of our host.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis said, he ceased. The king of men replies:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy years are awful, and thy words are wise.\r\nBut that imperious, that unconquer\xe2\x80\x99d soul,\r\nNo laws can limit, no respect control.\r\nBefore his pride must his superiors fall;\r\nHis word the law, and he the lord of all?\r\nHim must our hosts, our chiefs, ourself obey?\r\nWhat king can bear a rival in his sway?\r\nGrant that the gods his matchless force have given;\r\nHas foul reproach a privilege from heaven?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere on the monarch\xe2\x80\x99s speech Achilles broke,\r\nAnd furious, thus, and interrupting spoke:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTyrant, I well deserved thy galling chain,\r\nTo live thy slave, and still to serve in vain,\r\nShould I submit to each unjust decree:\xe2\x80\x94\r\nCommand thy vassals, but command not me.\r\nSeize on Briseis, whom the Grecians doom\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nMy prize of war, yet tamely see resumed;\r\nAnd seize secure; no more Achilles draws\r\nHis conquering sword in any woman\xe2\x80\x99s cause.\r\nThe gods command me to forgive the past:\r\nBut let this first invasion be the last:\r\nFor know, thy blood, when next thou darest invade,\r\nShall stream in vengeance on my reeking blade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this they ceased: the stern debate expired:\r\nThe chiefs in sullen majesty retired.\r\n\r\nAchilles with Patroclus took his way\r\nWhere near his tents his hollow vessels lay.\r\nMeantime Atrides launch\xe2\x80\x99d with numerous oars\r\nA well-rigg\xe2\x80\x99d ship for Chrysa\xe2\x80\x99s sacred shores:\r\nHigh on the deck was fair Chryseis placed,\r\nAnd sage Ulysses with the conduct graced:\r\nSafe in her sides the hecatomb they stow\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThen swiftly sailing, cut the liquid road.\r\n\r\nThe host to expiate next the king prepares,\r\nWith pure lustrations, and with solemn prayers.\r\nWash\xe2\x80\x99d by the briny wave, the pious train59\r\nAre cleansed; and cast the ablutions in the main.\r\nAlong the shore whole hecatombs were laid,\r\nAnd bulls and goats to Phoebus\xe2\x80\x99 altars paid;\r\nThe sable fumes in curling spires arise,\r\nAnd waft their grateful odours to the skies.\r\n\r\nThe army thus in sacred rites engaged,\r\nAtrides still with deep resentment raged.\r\nTo wait his will two sacred heralds stood,\r\nTalthybius and Eurybates the good.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaste to the fierce Achilles\xe2\x80\x99 tent (he cries),\r\nThence bear Briseis as our royal prize:\r\nSubmit he must; or if they will not part,\r\nOurself in arms shall tear her from his heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe unwilling heralds act their lord\xe2\x80\x99s commands;\r\nPensive they walk along the barren sands:\r\nArrived, the hero in his tent they find,\r\nWith gloomy aspect on his arm reclined.\r\nAt awful distance long they silent stand,\r\nLoth to advance, and speak their hard command;\r\nDecent confusion! This the godlike man\r\nPerceived, and thus with accent mild began:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith leave and honour enter our abodes,\r\nYe sacred ministers of men and gods!60\r\nI know your message; by constraint you came;\r\nNot you, but your imperious lord I blame.\r\nPatroclus, haste, the fair Briseis bring;\r\nConduct my captive to the haughty king.\r\nBut witness, heralds, and proclaim my vow,\r\nWitness to gods above, and men below!\r\nBut first, and loudest, to your prince declare\r\n(That lawless tyrant whose commands you bear),\r\nUnmoved as death Achilles shall remain,\r\nThough prostrate Greece shall bleed at every vein:\r\nThe raging chief in frantic passion lost,\r\nBlind to himself, and useless to his host,\r\nUnskill\xe2\x80\x99d to judge the future by the past,\r\nIn blood and slaughter shall repent at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THE DEPARTURE OF BRISEIS FROM THE TENT OF ACHILLES.]\r\n\r\nPatroclus now the unwilling beauty brought;\r\nShe, in soft sorrows, and in pensive thought,\r\nPass\xe2\x80\x99d silent, as the heralds held her hand,\r\nAnd oft look\xe2\x80\x99d back, slow-moving o\xe2\x80\x99er the strand.\r\nNot so his loss the fierce Achilles bore;\r\nBut sad, retiring to the sounding shore,\r\nO\xe2\x80\x99er the wild margin of the deep he hung,\r\nThat kindred deep from whence his mother sprung:61\r\nThere bathed in tears of anger and disdain,\r\nThus loud lamented to the stormy main:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO parent goddess! since in early bloom\r\nThy son must fall, by too severe a doom;\r\nSure to so short a race of glory born,\r\nGreat Jove in justice should this span adorn:\r\nHonour and fame at least the thunderer owed;\r\nAnd ill he pays the promise of a god,\r\nIf yon proud monarch thus thy son defies,\r\nObscures my glories, and resumes my prize.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFar from the deep recesses of the main,\r\nWhere aged Ocean holds his watery reign,\r\nThe goddess-mother heard. The waves divide;\r\nAnd like a mist she rose above the tide;\r\nBeheld him mourning on the naked shores,\r\nAnd thus the sorrows of his soul explores.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy grieves my son? Thy anguish let me share;\r\nReveal the cause, and trust a parent\xe2\x80\x99s care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe deeply sighing said: \xe2\x80\x9cTo tell my woe\r\nIs but to mention what too well you know.\r\nFrom Thebe, sacred to Apollo\xe2\x80\x99s name62\r\n(Aetion\xe2\x80\x99s realm), our conquering army came,\r\nWith treasure loaded and triumphant spoils,\r\nWhose just division crown\xe2\x80\x99d the soldier\xe2\x80\x99s toils;\r\nBut bright Chryseis, heavenly prize! was led,\r\nBy vote selected, to the general\xe2\x80\x99s bed.\r\nThe priest of Phoebus sought by gifts to gain\r\nHis beauteous daughter from the victor\xe2\x80\x99s chain;\r\nThe fleet he reach\xe2\x80\x99d, and, lowly bending down,\r\nHeld forth the sceptre and the laurel crown,\r\nIntreating all; but chief implored for grace\r\nThe brother-kings of Atreus\xe2\x80\x99 royal race:\r\nThe generous Greeks their joint consent declare,\r\nThe priest to reverence, and release the fair;\r\nNot so Atrides: he, with wonted pride,\r\nThe sire insulted, and his gifts denied:\r\nThe insulted sire (his god\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar care)\r\nTo Phoebus pray\xe2\x80\x99d, and Phoebus heard the prayer:\r\nA dreadful plague ensues: the avenging darts\r\nIncessant fly, and pierce the Grecian hearts.\r\nA prophet then, inspired by heaven, arose,\r\nAnd points the crime, and thence derives the woes:\r\nMyself the first the assembled chiefs incline\r\nTo avert the vengeance of the power divine;\r\nThen rising in his wrath, the monarch storm\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nIncensed he threaten\xe2\x80\x99d, and his threats perform\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\nThe fair Chryseis to her sire was sent,\r\nWith offer\xe2\x80\x99d gifts to make the god relent;\r\nBut now he seized Briseis\xe2\x80\x99 heavenly charms,\r\nAnd of my valour\xe2\x80\x99s prize defrauds my arms,\r\nDefrauds the votes of all the Grecian train;63\r\nAnd service, faith, and justice, plead in vain.\r\nBut, goddess! thou thy suppliant son attend.\r\nTo high Olympus\xe2\x80\x99 shining court ascend,\r\nUrge all the ties to former service owed,\r\nAnd sue for vengeance to the thundering god.\r\nOft hast thou triumph\xe2\x80\x99d in the glorious boast,\r\nThat thou stood\xe2\x80\x99st forth of all the ethereal host,\r\nWhen bold rebellion shook the realms above,\r\nThe undaunted guard of cloud-compelling Jove:\r\nWhen the bright partner of his awful reign,\r\nThe warlike maid, and monarch of the main,\r\nThe traitor-gods, by mad ambition driven,\r\nDurst threat with chains the omnipotence of Heaven.\r\nThen, call\xe2\x80\x99d by thee, the monster Titan came\r\n(Whom gods Briareus, men \xc3\x86geon name),\r\nThrough wondering skies enormous stalk\xe2\x80\x99d along;\r\nNot he that shakes the solid earth so strong:\r\nWith giant-pride at Jove\xe2\x80\x99s high throne he stands,\r\nAnd brandish\xe2\x80\x99d round him all his hundred hands:\r\nThe affrighted gods confess\xe2\x80\x99d their awful lord,\r\nThey dropp\xe2\x80\x99d the fetters, trembled, and adored.64\r\nThis, goddess, this to his remembrance call,\r\nEmbrace his knees, at his tribunal fall;\r\nConjure him far to drive the Grecian train,\r\nTo hurl them headlong to their fleet and main,\r\nTo heap the shores with copious death, and bring\r\nThe Greeks to know the curse of such a king.\r\nLet Agamemnon lift his haughty head\r\nO\xe2\x80\x99er all his wide dominion of the dead,\r\nAnd mourn in blood that e\xe2\x80\x99er he durst disgrace\r\nThe boldest warrior of the Grecian race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THETIS CALLING BRIAREUS TO THE ASSISTANCE OF JUPITER.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy son! (fair Thetis thus replies,\r\nWhile tears celestial trickle from her eyes)\r\nWhy have I borne thee with a mother\xe2\x80\x99s throes,\r\nTo Fates averse, and nursed for future woes?65\r\nSo short a space the light of heaven to view!\r\nSo short a space! and fill\xe2\x80\x99d with sorrow too!\r\nO might a parent\xe2\x80\x99s careful wish prevail,\r\nFar, far from Ilion should thy vessels sail,\r\nAnd thou, from camps remote, the danger shun\r\nWhich now, alas! too nearly threats my son.\r\nYet (what I can) to move thy suit I\xe2\x80\x99ll go\r\nTo great Olympus crown\xe2\x80\x99d with fleecy snow.\r\nMeantime, secure within thy ships, from far\r\nBehold the field, not mingle in the war.\r\nThe sire of gods and all the ethereal train,\r\nOn the warm limits of the farthest main,\r\nNow mix with mortals, nor disdain to grace\r\nThe feasts of \xc3\x86thiopia\xe2\x80\x99s blameless race,66\r\nTwelve days the powers indulge the genial rite,\r\nReturning with the twelfth revolving light.\r\nThen will I mount the brazen dome, and move\r\nThe high tribunal of immortal Jove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe goddess spoke: the rolling waves unclose;\r\nThen down the steep she plunged from whence she rose,\r\nAnd left him sorrowing on the lonely coast,\r\nIn wild resentment for the fair he lost.\r\n\r\nIn Chrysa\xe2\x80\x99s port now sage Ulysses rode;\r\nBeneath the deck the destined victims stow\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\nThe sails they furl\xe2\x80\x99d, they lash the mast aside,\r\nAnd dropp\xe2\x80\x99d their anchors, and the pinnace tied.\r\nNext on the shore their hecatomb they land;\r\nChryseis last descending on the strand.\r\nHer, thus returning from the furrow\xe2\x80\x99d main,\r\nUlysses led to Phoebus\xe2\x80\x99 sacred fane;\r\nWhere at his solemn altar, as the maid\r\nHe gave to Chryses, thus the hero said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHail, reverend priest! to Phoebus\xe2\x80\x99 awful dome\r\nA suppliant I from great Atrides come:\r\nUnransom\xe2\x80\x99d, here receive the spotless fair;\r\nAccept the hecatomb the Greeks prepare;\r\nAnd may thy god who scatters darts around,\r\nAtoned by sacrifice, desist to wound.\xe2\x80\x9d67\r\n\r\nAt this, the sire embraced the maid again,\r\nSo sadly lost, so lately sought in vain.\r\nThen near the altar of the darting king,\r\nDisposed in rank their hecatomb they bring;\r\nWith water purify their hands, and take\r\nThe sacred offering of the salted cake;\r\nWhile thus with arms devoutly raised in air,\r\nAnd solemn voice, the priest directs his prayer:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod of the silver bow, thy ear incline,\r\nWhose power incircles Cilla the divine;\r\nWhose sacred eye thy Tenedos surveys,\r\nAnd gilds fair Chrysa with distinguish\xe2\x80\x99d rays!\r\nIf, fired to vengeance at thy priest\xe2\x80\x99s request,\r\nThy direful darts inflict the raging pest:\r\nOnce more attend! avert the wasteful woe,\r\nAnd smile propitious, and unbend thy bow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo Chryses pray\xe2\x80\x99d. Apollo heard his prayer:\r\nAnd now the Greeks their hecatomb prepare;\r\nBetween their horns the salted barley threw,\r\nAnd, with their heads to heaven, the victims slew:68\r\nThe limbs they sever from the inclosing hide;\r\nThe thighs, selected to the gods, divide:\r\nOn these, in double cauls involved with art,\r\nThe choicest morsels lay from every part.\r\nThe priest himself before his altar stands,\r\nAnd burns the offering with his holy hands.\r\nPours the black wine, and sees the flames aspire;\r\nThe youth with instruments surround the fire:\r\nThe thighs thus sacrificed, and entrails dress\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThe assistants part, transfix, and roast the rest:\r\nThen spread the tables, the repast prepare;\r\nEach takes his seat, and each receives his share.\r\nWhen now the rage of hunger was repress\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nWith pure libations they conclude the feast;\r\nThe youths with wine the copious goblets crown\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAnd, pleased, dispense the flowing bowls around;69\r\nWith hymns divine the joyous banquet ends,\r\nThe paeans lengthen\xe2\x80\x99d till the sun descends:\r\nThe Greeks, restored, the grateful notes prolong;\r\nApollo listens, and approves the song.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Twas night; the chiefs beside their vessel lie,\r\nTill rosy morn had purpled o\xe2\x80\x99er the sky:\r\nThen launch, and hoist the mast: indulgent gales,\r\nSupplied by Phoebus, fill the swelling sails;\r\nThe milk-white canvas bellying as they blow,\r\nThe parted ocean foams and roars below:\r\nAbove the bounding billows swift they flew,\r\nTill now the Grecian camp appear\xe2\x80\x99d in view.\r\nFar on the beach they haul their bark to land,\r\n(The crooked keel divides the yellow sand,)\r\nThen part, where stretch\xe2\x80\x99d along the winding bay,\r\nThe ships and tents in mingled prospect lay.\r\n\r\nBut raging still, amidst his navy sat\r\nThe stern Achilles, stedfast in his hate;\r\nNor mix\xe2\x80\x99d in combat, nor in council join\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nBut wasting cares lay heavy on his mind:\r\nIn his black thoughts revenge and slaughter roll,\r\nAnd scenes of blood rise dreadful in his soul.\r\n\r\nTwelve days were past, and now the dawning light\r\nThe gods had summon\xe2\x80\x99d to the Olympian height:\r\nJove, first ascending from the watery bowers,\r\nLeads the long order of ethereal powers.\r\nWhen, like the morning-mist in early day,\r\nRose from the flood the daughter of the sea:\r\nAnd to the seats divine her flight address\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nThere, far apart, and high above the rest,\r\nThe thunderer sat; where old Olympus shrouds\r\nHis hundred heads in heaven, and props the clouds.\r\nSuppliant the goddess stood: one hand she placed\r\nBeneath his beard, and one his knees embraced.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf e\xe2\x80\x99er, O father of the gods! (she said)\r\nMy words could please thee, or my actions aid,\r\nSome marks of honour on my son bestow,\r\nAnd pay in glory what in life you owe.\r\nFame is at least by heavenly promise due\r\nTo life so short, and now dishonour\xe2\x80\x99d too.\r\nAvenge this wrong, O ever just and wise!\r\nLet Greece be humbled, and the Trojans rise;\r\nTill the proud king and all the Achaian race\r\nShall heap with honours him they now disgrace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THETIS ENTREATING JUPITER TO HONOUR ACHILLES.]\r\n\r\nThus Thetis spoke; but Jove in silence held\r\nThe sacred counsels of his breast conceal\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nNot so repulsed, the goddess closer press\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nStill grasp\xe2\x80\x99d his knees, and urged the dear request.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO sire of gods and men! thy suppliant hear;\r\nRefuse, or grant; for what has Jove to fear?\r\nOr oh! declare, of all the powers above,\r\nIs wretched Thetis least the care of Jove?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe said; and, sighing, thus the god replies,\r\nWho rolls the thunder o\xe2\x80\x99er the vaulted skies:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat hast thou ask\xe2\x80\x99d? ah, why should Jove engage\r\nIn foreign contests and domestic rage,\r\nThe gods\xe2\x80\x99 complaints, and Juno\xe2\x80\x99s fierce alarms,\r\nWhile I, too partial, aid the Trojan arms?\r\nGo, lest the haughty partner of my sway\r\nWith jealous eyes thy close access survey;\r\nBut part in peace, secure thy prayer is sped:\r\nWitness the sacred honours of our head,\r\nThe nod that ratifies the will divine,\r\nThe faithful, fix\xe2\x80\x99d, irrevocable sign;\r\nThis seals thy suit, and this fulfils thy vows\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe spoke, and awful bends his sable brows,70\r\nShakes his ambrosial curls, and gives the nod,\r\nThe stamp of fate and sanction of the god:\r\nHigh heaven with trembling the dread signal took,\r\nAnd all Olympus to the centre shook.71\r\n\r\nSwift to the seas profound the goddess flies,\r\nJove to his starry mansions in the skies.\r\nThe shining synod of the immortals wait\r\nThe coming god, and from their thrones of state\r\nArising silent, wrapp\xe2\x80\x99d in holy fear,\r\nBefore the majesty of heaven appear.\r\nTrembling they stand, while Jove assumes the throne,\r\nAll, but the god\xe2\x80\x99s imperious queen alone:\r\nLate had she view\xe2\x80\x99d the silver-footed dame,\r\nAnd all her passions kindled into flame.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, artful manager of heaven (she cries),\r\nWho now partakes the secrets of the skies?\r\nThy Juno knows not the decrees of fate,\r\nIn vain the partner of imperial state.\r\nWhat favourite goddess then those cares divides,\r\nWhich Jove in prudence from his consort hides?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this the thunderer: \xe2\x80\x9cSeek not thou to find\r\nThe sacred counsels of almighty mind:\r\nInvolved in darkness lies the great decree,\r\nNor can the depths of fate be pierced by thee.\r\nWhat fits thy knowledge, thou the first shalt know;\r\nThe first of gods above, and men below;\r\nBut thou, nor they, shall search the thoughts that roll\r\nDeep in the close recesses of my soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFull on the sire the goddess of the skies\r\nRoll\xe2\x80\x99d the large orbs of her majestic eyes,\r\nAnd thus return\xe2\x80\x99d:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAustere Saturnius, say,\r\nFrom whence this wrath, or who controls thy sway?\r\nThy boundless will, for me, remains in force,\r\nAnd all thy counsels take the destined course.\r\nBut \xe2\x80\x99tis for Greece I fear: for late was seen,\r\nIn close consult, the silver-footed queen.\r\nJove to his Thetis nothing could deny,\r\nNor was the signal vain that shook the sky.\r\nWhat fatal favour has the goddess won,\r\nTo grace her fierce, inexorable son?\r\nPerhaps in Grecian blood to drench the plain,\r\nAnd glut his vengeance with my people slain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen thus the god: \xe2\x80\x9cO restless fate of pride,\r\nThat strives to learn what heaven resolves to hide;\r\nVain is the search, presumptuous and abhorr\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAnxious to thee, and odious to thy lord.\r\nLet this suffice: the immutable decree\r\nNo force can shake: what is, that ought to be.\r\nGoddess, submit; nor dare our will withstand,\r\nBut dread the power of this avenging hand:\r\nThe united strength of all the gods above\r\nIn vain resists the omnipotence of Jove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration: VULCAN.]\r\n\r\nThe thunderer spoke, nor durst the queen reply;\r\nA reverent horror silenced all the sky.\r\nThe feast disturb\xe2\x80\x99d, with sorrow Vulcan saw\r\nHis mother menaced, and the gods in awe;\r\nPeace at his heart, and pleasure his design,\r\nThus interposed the architect divine:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wretched quarrels of the mortal state\r\nAre far unworthy, gods! of your debate:\r\nLet men their days in senseless strife employ,\r\nWe, in eternal peace and constant joy.\r\nThou, goddess-mother, with our sire comply,\r\nNor break the sacred union of the sky:\r\nLest, roused to rage, he shake the bless\xe2\x80\x99d abodes,\r\nLaunch the red lightning, and dethrone the gods.\r\nIf you submit, the thunderer stands appeased;\r\nThe gracious power is willing to be pleased.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus Vulcan spoke: and rising with a bound,\r\nThe double bowl with sparkling nectar crown\xe2\x80\x99d,72\r\nWhich held to Juno in a cheerful way,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoddess (he cried), be patient and obey.\r\nDear as you are, if Jove his arm extend,\r\nI can but grieve, unable to defend.\r\nWhat god so daring in your aid to move,\r\nOr lift his hand against the force of Jove?\r\nOnce in your cause I felt his matchless might,\r\nHurl\xe2\x80\x99d headlong down from the ethereal height;73\r\nToss\xe2\x80\x99d all the day in rapid circles round,\r\nNor till the sun descended touch\xe2\x80\x99d the ground.\r\nBreathless I fell, in giddy motion lost;\r\nThe Sinthians raised me on the Lemnian coast;74\r\n\r\nHe said, and to her hands the goblet heaved,\r\nWhich, with a smile, the white-arm\xe2\x80\x99d queen received\r\nThen, to the rest he fill\xe2\x80\x99d; and in his turn,\r\nEach to his lips applied the nectar\xe2\x80\x99d urn,\r\nVulcan with awkward grace his office plies,\r\nAnd unextinguish\xe2\x80\x99d laughter shakes the skies.\r\n\r\nThus the blest gods the genial day prolong,\r\nIn feasts ambrosial, and celestial song.75\r\nApollo tuned the lyre; the Muses round\r\nWith voice alternate aid the silver sound.\r\nMeantime the radiant sun to mortal sight\r\nDescending swift, roll\xe2\x80\x99d down the rapid light:\r\nThen to their starry domes the gods depart,\r\nThe shining monuments of Vulcan\xe2\x80\x99s art:\r\nJove on his couch reclined his awful head,\r\nAnd Juno slumber\xe2\x80\x99d on the golden bed.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: JUPITER.]\r\n\r\n[Illustration: THE APOTHEOSIS OF HOMER.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK II.\r\n\r\nARGUMENT.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE TRIAL OF THE ARMY, AND CATALOGUE OF THE FORCES.\r\n\r\nJupiter, in pursuance of the request of Thetis, sends a deceitful\r\nvision to Agamemnon, persuading him to lead the army to battle, in\r\norder to make the Greeks sensible of their want of Achilles. The\r\ngeneral, who is deluded with the hopes of taking Troy without his\r\nassistance, but fears the army was discouraged by his absence, and the\r\nlate plague, as well as by the length of time, contrives to make trial\r\nof their disposition by a stratagem. He first communicates his design\r\nto the princes in council, that he would propose a return to the\r\nsoldiers, and that they should put a stop to them if the proposal was\r\nembraced. Then he assembles the whole host, and upon moving for a\r\nreturn to Greece, they unanimously agree to it, and run to prepare the\r\nships. They are detained by the management of Ulysses, who chastises\r\nthe insolence of Thersites. The assembly is recalled, several speeches\r\nmade on the occasion, and at length the advice of Nestor followed,\r\nwhich was to make a general muster of the troops, and to divide them\r\ninto their several nations, before they proceeded to battle. This gives\r\noccasion to the poet to enumerate all the forces of the Greeks and\r\nTrojans, and in a large catalogue.\r\n\r\nThe time employed in this book consists not entirely of one day. The\r\nscene lies in the Grecian camp, and upon the sea-shore; towards the end\r\nit removes to Troy.\r\n\r\nNow pleasing sleep had seal\xe2\x80\x99d each mortal eye,\r\nStretch\xe2\x80\x99d in the tents the Grecian leaders lie:\r\nThe immortals slumber\xe2\x80\x99d on their thrones above;\r\nAll, but the ever-wakeful eyes of Jove.76\r\nTo honour Thetis\xe2\x80\x99 son he bends his care,\r\nAnd plunge the Greeks in all the woes of war:\r\nThen bids an empty phantom rise to sight,\r\nAnd thus commands the vision of the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFly hence, deluding Dream! and light as air,77\r\nTo Agamemnon\xe2\x80\x99s ample tent repair.\r\nBid him in arms draw forth the embattled train,\r\nLead all his Grecians to the dusty plain.\r\nDeclare, e\xe2\x80\x99en now \xe2\x80\x99tis given him to destroy\r\nThe lofty towers of wide-extended Troy.\r\nFor now no more the gods with fate contend,\r\nAt Juno\xe2\x80\x99s suit the heavenly factions end.\r\nDestruction hangs o\xe2\x80\x99er yon devoted wall,\r\nAnd nodding Ilion waits the impending fall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSwift as the word the vain illusion fled,\r\nDescends, and hovers o\xe2\x80\x99er Atrides\xe2\x80\x99 head;\r\nClothed in the figure of the Pylian sage,\r\nRenown\xe2\x80\x99d for wisdom, and revered for age:\r\nAround his temples spreads his golden wing,\r\nAnd thus the flattering dream deceives the king.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: JUPITER SENDING THE EVIL DREAM TO AGAMEMNON.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCanst thou, with all a monarch\xe2\x80\x99s cares oppress\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nO Atreus\xe2\x80\x99 son! canst thou indulge thy rest?78\r\nIll fits a chief who mighty nations guides,\r\nDirects in council, and in war presides,\r\nTo whom its safety a whole people owes,\r\nTo waste long nights in indolent repose.79\r\nMonarch, awake! \xe2\x80\x99tis Jove\xe2\x80\x99s command I bear;\r\nThou, and thy glory, claim his heavenly care.\r\nIn just array draw forth the embattled train,\r\nLead all thy Grecians to the dusty plain;\r\nE\xe2\x80\x99en now, O king! \xe2\x80\x99tis given thee to destroy\r\nThe lofty towers of wide-extended Troy.\r\nFor now no more the gods with fate contend,\r\nAt Juno\xe2\x80\x99s suit the heavenly factions end.\r\nDestruction hangs o\xe2\x80\x99er yon devoted wall,\r\nAnd nodding Ilion waits the impending fall.\r\nAwake, but waking this advice approve,\r\nAnd trust the vision that descends from Jove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe phantom said; then vanish\xe2\x80\x99d from his sight,\r\nResolves to air, and mixes with the night.\r\nA thousand schemes the monarch\xe2\x80\x99s mind employ;\r\nElate in thought he sacks untaken Troy:\r\nVain as he was, and to the future blind,\r\nNor saw what Jove and secret fate design\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nWhat mighty toils to either host remain,\r\nWhat scenes of grief, and numbers of the slain!\r\nEager he rises, and in fancy hears\r\nThe voice celestial murmuring in his ears.\r\nFirst on his limbs a slender vest he drew,\r\nAround him next the regal mantle threw,\r\nThe embroider\xe2\x80\x99d sandals on his feet were tied;\r\nThe starry falchion glitter\xe2\x80\x99d at his side;\r\nAnd last, his arm the massy sceptre loads,\r\nUnstain\xe2\x80\x99d, immortal, and the gift of gods.\r\n\r\nNow rosy Morn ascends the court of Jove,\r\nLifts up her light, and opens day above.\r\nThe king despatch\xe2\x80\x99d his heralds with commands\r\nTo range the camp and summon all the bands:\r\nThe gathering hosts the monarch\xe2\x80\x99s word obey;\r\nWhile to the fleet Atrides bends his way.\r\nIn his black ship the Pylian prince he found;\r\nThere calls a senate of the peers around:\r\nThe assembly placed, the king of men express\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThe counsels labouring in his artful breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriends and confederates! with attentive ear\r\nReceive my words, and credit what you hear.\r\nLate as I slumber\xe2\x80\x99d in the shades of night,\r\nA dream divine appear\xe2\x80\x99d before my sight;\r\nWhose visionary form like Nestor came,\r\nThe same in habit, and in mien the same.80\r\nThe heavenly phantom hover\xe2\x80\x99d o\xe2\x80\x99er my head,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And, dost thou sleep, O Atreus\xe2\x80\x99 son? (he said)\r\nIll fits a chief who mighty nations guides,\r\nDirects in council, and in war presides;\r\nTo whom its safety a whole people owes,\r\nTo waste long nights in indolent repose.\r\nMonarch, awake! \xe2\x80\x99tis Jove\xe2\x80\x99s command I bear,\r\nThou and thy glory claim his heavenly care.\r\nIn just array draw forth the embattled train,\r\nAnd lead the Grecians to the dusty plain;\r\nE\xe2\x80\x99en now, O king! \xe2\x80\x99tis given thee to destroy\r\nThe lofty towers of wide-extended Troy.\r\nFor now no more the gods with fate contend,\r\nAt Juno\xe2\x80\x99s suit the heavenly factions end.\r\nDestruction hangs o\xe2\x80\x99er yon devoted wall,\r\nAnd nodding Ilion waits the impending fall.\r\n\r\nThis hear observant, and the gods obey!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThe vision spoke, and pass\xe2\x80\x99d in air away.\r\nNow, valiant chiefs! since heaven itself alarms,\r\nUnite, and rouse the sons of Greece to arms.\r\nBut first, with caution, try what yet they dare,\r\nWorn with nine years of unsuccessful war.\r\nTo move the troops to measure back the main,\r\nBe mine; and yours the province to detain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe spoke, and sat: when Nestor, rising said,\r\n(Nestor, whom Pylos\xe2\x80\x99 sandy realms obey\xe2\x80\x99d,)\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrinces of Greece, your faithful ears incline,\r\nNor doubt the vision of the powers divine;\r\nSent by great Jove to him who rules the host,\r\nForbid it, heaven! this warning should be lost!\r\nThen let us haste, obey the god\xe2\x80\x99s alarms,\r\nAnd join to rouse the sons of Greece to arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the sage: the kings without delay\r\nDissolve the council, and their chief obey:\r\nThe sceptred rulers lead; the following host,\r\nPour\xe2\x80\x99d forth by thousands, darkens all the coast.\r\nAs from some rocky cleft the shepherd sees\r\nClustering in heaps on heaps the driving bees,\r\nRolling and blackening, swarms succeeding swarms,\r\nWith deeper murmurs and more hoarse alarms;\r\nDusky they spread, a close embodied crowd,\r\nAnd o\xe2\x80\x99er the vale descends the living cloud.81\r\nSo, from the tents and ships, a lengthen\xe2\x80\x99d train\r\nSpreads all the beach, and wide o\xe2\x80\x99ershades the plain:\r\nAlong the region runs a deafening sound;\r\nBeneath their footsteps groans the trembling ground.\r\nFame flies before the messenger of Jove,\r\nAnd shining soars, and claps her wings above.\r\nNine sacred heralds now, proclaiming loud82\r\nThe monarch\xe2\x80\x99s will, suspend the listening crowd.\r\nSoon as the throngs in order ranged appear,\r\nAnd fainter murmurs died upon the ear,\r\nThe king of kings his awful figure raised:\r\nHigh in his hand the golden sceptre blazed;\r\nThe golden sceptre, of celestial flame,\r\nBy Vulcan form\xe2\x80\x99d, from Jove to Hermes came.\r\nTo Pelops he the immortal gift resign\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nThe immortal gift great Pelops left behind,\r\nIn Atreus\xe2\x80\x99 hand, which not with Atreus ends,\r\nTo rich Thyestes next the prize descends;\r\nAnd now the mark of Agamemnon\xe2\x80\x99s reign,\r\nSubjects all Argos, and controls the main.83\r\n\r\nOn this bright sceptre now the king reclined,\r\nAnd artful thus pronounced the speech design\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe sons of Mars, partake your leader\xe2\x80\x99s care,\r\nHeroes of Greece, and brothers of the war!\r\nOf partial Jove with justice I complain,\r\nAnd heavenly oracles believed in vain\r\nA safe return was promised to our toils,\r\nRenown\xe2\x80\x99d, triumphant, and enrich\xe2\x80\x99d with spoils.\r\nNow shameful flight alone can save the host,\r\nOur blood, our treasure, and our glory lost.\r\nSo Jove decrees, resistless lord of all!\r\nAt whose command whole empires rise or fall:\r\nHe shakes the feeble props of human trust,\r\nAnd towns and armies humbles to the dust.\r\nWhat shame to Greece a fruitful war to wage,\r\nOh, lasting shame in every future age!\r\nOnce great in arms, the common scorn we grow,\r\nRepulsed and baffled by a feeble foe.\r\nSo small their number, that if wars were ceased,\r\nAnd Greece triumphant held a general feast,\r\nAll rank\xe2\x80\x99d by tens, whole decades when they dine\r\nMust want a Trojan slave to pour the wine.84\r\nBut other forces have our hopes o\xe2\x80\x99erthrown,\r\nAnd Troy prevails by armies not her own.\r\nNow nine long years of mighty Jove are run,\r\nSince first the labours of this war begun:\r\nOur cordage torn, decay\xe2\x80\x99d our vessels lie,\r\nAnd scarce insure the wretched power to fly.\r\nHaste, then, for ever leave the Trojan wall!\r\nOur weeping wives, our tender children call:\r\nLove, duty, safety, summon us away,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis nature\xe2\x80\x99s voice, and nature we obey.\r\nOur shatter\xe2\x80\x99d barks may yet transport us o\xe2\x80\x99er,\r\nSafe and inglorious, to our native shore.\r\nFly, Grecians, fly, your sails and oars employ,\r\nAnd dream no more of heaven-defended Troy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis deep design unknown, the hosts approve\r\nAtrides\xe2\x80\x99 speech. The mighty numbers move.\r\nSo roll the billows to the Icarian shore,\r\nFrom east and south when winds begin to roar,\r\nBurst their dark mansions in the clouds, and sweep\r\nThe whitening surface of the ruffled deep.\r\nAnd as on corn when western gusts descend,85\r\nBefore the blast the lofty harvests bend:\r\nThus o\xe2\x80\x99er the field the moving host appears,\r\nWith nodding plumes and groves of waving spears.\r\nThe gathering murmur spreads, their trampling feet\r\nBeat the loose sands, and thicken to the fleet;\r\nWith long-resounding cries they urge the train\r\nTo fit the ships, and launch into the main.\r\nThey toil, they sweat, thick clouds of dust arise,\r\nThe doubling clamours echo to the skies.\r\nE\xe2\x80\x99en then the Greeks had left the hostile plain,\r\nAnd fate decreed the fall of Troy in vain;\r\nBut Jove\xe2\x80\x99s imperial queen their flight survey\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAnd sighing thus bespoke the blue-eyed maid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall then the Grecians fly! O dire disgrace!\r\nAnd leave unpunish\xe2\x80\x99d this perfidious race?\r\nShall Troy, shall Priam, and the adulterous spouse,\r\nIn peace enjoy the fruits of broken vows?\r\nAnd bravest chiefs, in Helen\xe2\x80\x99s quarrel slain,\r\nLie unrevenged on yon detested plain?\r\nNo: let my Greeks, unmoved by vain alarms,\r\nOnce more refulgent shine in brazen arms.\r\nHaste, goddess, haste! the flying host detain,\r\nNor let one sail be hoisted on the main.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPallas obeys, and from Olympus\xe2\x80\x99 height\r\nSwift to the ships precipitates her flight.\r\nUlysses, first in public cares, she found,\r\nFor prudent counsel like the gods renown\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\nOppress\xe2\x80\x99d with generous grief the hero stood,\r\nNor drew his sable vessels to the flood.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is it thus, divine Laertes\xe2\x80\x99 son,\r\nThus fly the Greeks (the martial maid begun),\r\nThus to their country bear their own disgrace,\r\nAnd fame eternal leave to Priam\xe2\x80\x99s race?\r\nShall beauteous Helen still remain unfreed,\r\nStill unrevenged, a thousand heroes bleed!\r\nHaste, generous Ithacus! prevent the shame,\r\nRecall your armies, and your chiefs reclaim.\r\nYour own resistless eloquence employ,\r\nAnd to the immortals trust the fall of Troy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice divine confess\xe2\x80\x99d the warlike maid,\r\nUlysses heard, nor uninspired obey\xe2\x80\x99d:\r\nThen meeting first Atrides, from his hand\r\nReceived the imperial sceptre of command.\r\nThus graced, attention and respect to gain,\r\nHe runs, he flies through all the Grecian train;\r\nEach prince of name, or chief in arms approved,\r\nHe fired with praise, or with persuasion moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWarriors like you, with strength and wisdom Greeks his fury may provoke;\r\nNot thus the king in secret council spoke.\r\nJove loves our chief, from Jove his honour springs,\r\nBeware! for dreadful is the wrath of kings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut crowd.\r\nTo one sole monarch Jove commits the sway;\r\nHis are the laws, and him let all obey.\xe2\x80\x9d86\r\n\r\nWith words like these the troops Ulysses ruled,\r\nThe loudest silenced, and the fiercest cool\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\nBack to the assembly roll the thronging train,\r\nDesert the ships, and pour upon the plain.\r\nMurmuring they move, as when old ocean roars,\r\nAnd heaves huge surges to the trembling shores;\r\nThe groaning banks are burst with bellowing sound,\r\nThe rocks remurmur and the deeps rebound.\r\nAt length the tumult sinks, the noises cease,\r\nAnd a still silence lulls the camp to peace.\r\nThersites only clamour\xe2\x80\x99d in the throng,\r\nLoquacious, loud, and turbulent of tongue:\r\nAwed by no shame, by no respect controll\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nIn scandal busy, in reproaches bold:\r\nWith witty malice studious to defame,\r\nScorn all his joy, and laughter all his aim:\xe2\x80\x94\r\nBut chief he gloried with licentious style\r\nTo lash the great, and royal scandal his delight supreme,\r\nLong had he lived the scorn of every Greek,\r\nVex\xe2\x80\x99d when he spoke, yet still they heard him speak.\r\nSharp was his voice; which in the shrillest Is it thirst of gold?\r\nSay, shall we march with our unconquer\xe2\x80\x99d powers\r\n(The Greeks and I) to Ilion\xe2\x80\x99s hostile towers,\r\nAnd bring the race of royal bastards here,\r\nFor he forced the prize we jointly gave,\r\nFrom him, the fierce, the fearless, and the brave:\r\nAnd durst he, as he ought, resent that wrong,\r\nThis mighty tyrant were no tyrant long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFierce from his seat at this Ulysses springs,87\r\nIn generous vengeance of the king of kings.\r\nWith indignation sparkling in his eyes,\r\nHe views the wretch, and sternly neighbour each express\xe2\x80\x99d his thought:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe gods! what wonders has Ulysses wrought!\r\nWhat fruits his conduct and his courage yield!\r\nGreat in the council, glorious in support the war.\r\nFor while around we gazed with wondering eyes,\r\nAnd trembling sought the powers with sacrifice,\r\nFull of his god, the reverend Chalcas cried,90\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ye Grecian warriors! lay your fears aside.\r\nThis wondrous signal Jove himself displays,\r\nOf long, long labours, but eternal praise.\r\nAs many birds as by the snake were slain,\r\nSo many years the toils of Greece remain;\r\nBut wait the tenth, for Ilion\xe2\x80\x99s fall decreed:\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThus spoke the prophet, thus the Fates succeed.\r\nObey, ye Grecians! with submission wait,\r\nNor let your flight avert the Trojan fate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe said: the shores with loud applauses sound,\r\nThe hollow ships each deafening shout rebound.\r\nThen Nestor thus\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThese vain debates forbear,\r\nYe talk like children, not like heroes dare.\r\nWhere now are all your high resolves at last?\r\nYour leagues concluded, your engagements past?\r\nVow\xe2\x80\x99d with libations mighty Jove prepares,\r\nAnd view with envy our successful wars.\r\nOn that great day, when first the martial train,\r\nBig with the fate of Ilion, plough\xe2\x80\x99d the main,\r\nJove, on the right, a prosperous signal sent,\r\nAnd thunder rolling shook the firmament.\r\nEncouraged hence, maintain the glorious strife,\r\nTill every soldier grasp a Phrygian wife,\r\nTill Helen\xe2\x80\x99s woes at sweat be every manly breast,\r\nWith the huge shield each brawny arm depress\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nEach aching nerve refuse the lance to throw,\r\nAnd each spent courser at the chariot blow.\r\nWho dares, inglorious, in his ships to stay,\r\nWho dares to tremble on this signal day;\r\nThat wretch, too mean to fall by martial power,\r\nThe birds shall mangle, and the dogs devour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe monarch spoke; and straight a murmur rose,\r\nLoud as the surges when the tempest blows,\r\nThat dash\xe2\x80\x99d on broken rocks tumultuous roar,\r\nAnd foam and thunder on the stony day.\r\nA steer of five years\xe2\x80\x99 age, large limb\xe2\x80\x99d, and fed,92\r\nTo Jove\xe2\x80\x99s high altars Agamemnon led:\r\nThere bade the noblest of the Grecian peers;\r\nAnd Nestor Jove\xe2\x80\x99s immortal shield,\r\nBlazed on her arm, and lighten\xe2\x80\x99d all the field:\r\nRound the vast orb a hundred serpents roll\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nForm\xe2\x80\x99d the bright fringe, and seem\xe2\x80\x99d to burn in gold,\r\nWith this each Grecian\xe2\x80\x99s manly breast she warms,\r\nSwells their bold hearts, and strings their nervous arms,\r\nNo more they sigh, inglorious, to return,\r\nBut breathe revenge, and for the combat burn.\r\n\r\nAs on some mountain, through the lofty grove,\r\nThe crackling flames ascend, and blaze above;\r\nThe fires expanding, as the winds arise,\r\nShoot their long beams, and kindle half the skies:\r\nSo from the polish\xe2\x80\x99d arms, and brazen shields,\r\nA gleamy splendour flash\xe2\x80\x99d along the fields.\r\nNot less their number than the embodied cranes,\r\nOr milk-white swans in Asius\xe2\x80\x99 watery plains.\r\nThat, o\xe2\x80\x99er the windings of Cayster\xe2\x80\x99s springs,97\r\nStretch their long necks, and clap their rustling wings,\r\nNow tower aloft, and course in airy rounds,\r\nNow light with noise; with noise the field resounds.\r\nThus numerous and confused, extending wide,\r\nThe legions crowd Scamander\xe2\x80\x99s flowery side;98\r\nWith rushing troops the plains are cover\xe2\x80\x99d o\xe2\x80\x99er,\r\nAnd thundering footsteps shake the sounding shore.\r\nAlong the river\xe2\x80\x99s level meads they stand,\r\nThick as in spring the flowers adorn the land,\r\nOr leaves the trees; or thick as insects play,\r\nThe wandering nation of a summer\xe2\x80\x99s day:\r\nThat, drawn by milky steams, at evening hours,\r\nIn gather\xe2\x80\x99d swarms surround the rural bowers;\r\nFrom pail to pail with busy murmur run\r\nThe gilded legions, glittering in the sun.\r\nSo throng\xe2\x80\x99d, so close, the Grecian squadrons stood\r\nIn radiant arms, and thirst for Trojan blood.\r\nEach leader now his scatter\xe2\x80\x99d force conjoins\r\nIn close array, and forms the deepening lines.\r\nNot with more ease the skilful shepherd-swain\r\nCollects his flocks from thousands on the plain.\r\nThe king of kings, majestically tall,\r\nTowers o\xe2\x80\x99er his armies, and outshines them all;\r\nLike some proud bull, that round the pastures leads\r\nHis subject herds, the monarch of the meads,\r\nGreat as the gods, the exalted chief was seen,\r\nHis strength like Neptune, and like Mars his mien;99\r\nJove o\xe2\x80\x99er his eyes celestial glories spread,\r\nAnd dawning conquest played around his head.\r\n\r\nSay, virgins, seated round the throne divine,\r\nAll-knowing goddesses! immortal nine!100\r\nSince earth\xe2\x80\x99s wide regions, heaven\xe2\x80\x99s umneasur\xe2\x80\x99d height,\r\nAnd hell\xe2\x80\x99s abyss, hide nothing from your sight,\r\n(We, wretched mortals! lost in doubts below,\r\nBut guess by rumour, and but boast we know,)\r\nO say what heroes, fired by thirst of fame,\r\nOr urged by wrongs, to Troy\xe2\x80\x99s destruction came.\r\nTo count them all, demands a thousand tongues,\r\nA throat of brass, and adamantine lungs.\r\nDaughters of Jove, assist! inspired by you\r\nThe mighty labour dauntless I pursue;\r\nWhat crowded armies, from what climes they bring,\r\nTheir names, their numbers, and their chiefs I sing.\r\n\r\nTHE CATALOGUE OF THE SHIPS.101\r\n\r\n[Illustration: NEPTUNE.]\r\n\r\nThe hardy warriors whom Boeotia bred,\r\nPenelius, Leitus, Prothoenor, led:\r\nWith these Arcesilaus and Clonius stand,\r\nEqual in arms, and equal in command.\r\nThese head the troops that rocky Aulis yields,\r\nAnd Eteon\xe2\x80\x99s hills, and Hyrie\xe2\x80\x99s watery fields,\r\nAnd Schoenos, Scholos, Graea near the main,\r\nAnd Mycalessia\xe2\x80\x99s ample piny plain;\r\nThose who in Peteon or Ilesion dwell,\r\nOr Harma where Apollo\xe2\x80\x99s prophet fell;\r\nHeleon and Hyle, which the springs o\xe2\x80\x99erflow;\r\nAnd Medeon lofty, and Ocalea low;\r\nOr in the meads of Haliartus stray,\r\nOr Thespia sacred to the god of day:\r\nOnchestus, Neptune\xe2\x80\x99s celebrated groves;\r\nCopae, and Thisbe, famed for silver doves;\r\nFor flocks Erythrae, Glissa for the vine;\r\nPlatea green, and Nysa the divine;\r\nAnd they whom Thebe\xe2\x80\x99s well-built walls inclose,\r\nWhere Myde, Eutresis, Corone, rose;\r\nAnd Arne rich, with purple harvests crown\xe2\x80\x99d;\r\nAnd Anthedon, Boeotia\xe2\x80\x99s utmost bound.\r\nFull fifty ships they send, and each conveys\r\nTwice sixty warriors through the foaming seas.102\r\n\r\nTo these succeed Aspledon\xe2\x80\x99s martial train,\r\nWho plough the spacious Orchomenian plain.\r\nTwo valiant brothers rule the undaunted throng,\r\nIalmen and Ascalaphus the strong:\r\nSons of Astyoche, the heavenly fair,\r\nWhose virgin charms subdued the god of war:\r\n(In Actor\xe2\x80\x99s court as she retired to rest,\r\nThe strength of Mars the blushing maid compress\xe2\x80\x99d)\r\nTheir troops in thirty sable vessels sweep,\r\nWith equal oars, the hoarse-resounding deep.\r\n\r\nThe Phocians next in forty barks repair;\r\nEpistrophus and Schedius head the war:\r\nFrom those rich regions where Cephisus leads\r\nHis silver current through the flowery meads;\r\nFrom Panopea, Chrysa the divine,\r\nWhere Anemoria\xe2\x80\x99s stately turrets shine,\r\nWhere Pytho, Daulis, Cyparissus stood,\r\nAnd fair Lilaea views the rising flood.\r\nThese, ranged in order on the floating tide,\r\nClose, on the left, the bold Boeotians\xe2\x80\x99 side.\r\n\r\nFierce Ajax led the Locrian squadrons on,\r\nAjax the less, Oileus\xe2\x80\x99 valiant son;\r\nSkill\xe2\x80\x99d to direct the flying dart aright;\r\nSwift in pursuit, and active in the fight.\r\nHim, as their chief, the chosen troops attend,\r\nWhich Bessa, Thronus, and rich Cynos send;\r\nOpus, Calliarus, and Scarphe\xe2\x80\x99s bands;\r\nAnd those who dwell where pleasing Augia stands,\r\nAnd where Boagrius floats the lowly lands,\r\nOr in fair Tarphe\xe2\x80\x99s sylvan seats reside:\r\nIn forty vessels cut the yielding tide.\r\n\r\nEuboea next her martial sons prepares,\r\nAnd sends the brave Abantes to the wars:\r\nBreathing revenge, in arms they take their way\r\nFrom Chalcis\xe2\x80\x99 walls, and strong Eretria;\r\nThe Isteian fields for generous vines renown\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThe fair Caristos, and hands dismiss not the long lance in air;\r\nBut with protended spears in fighting fields\r\nPierce the tough corslets and the brazen shields.\r\nTwice twenty ships transport the warlike bands,\r\nWhich bold Elphenor, fierce in arms, commands.\r\n\r\nFull fifty more from Athens stem the main,\r\nLed by Menestheus through the liquid plain.\r\n(Athens the fair, where great Erectheus sway\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThat owed his nurture to the blue-eyed maid,\r\nBut from the teeming furrow took his birth,\r\nThe mighty offspring of the foodful earth.\r\nHim Pallas placed amidst her wealthy fane,\r\nAdored with sacrifice and oxen slain;\r\nWhere, as the years revolve, her altars blaze,\r\nAnd all the tribes resound the goddess\xe2\x80\x99 praise.)\r\nNo chief like thee, Menestheus! Greece could yield,\r\nTo marshal armies in the dusty field,\r\nThe extended wings of battle to display,\r\nOr close the embodied host in firm array.\r\nNestor alone, improved by length of course,\r\nAnd with the great Athenians join their force.\r\n\r\nNext move to war the generous Argive train,\r\nFrom high Troezene, and Maseta\xe2\x80\x99s plain,\r\nAnd fair \xc3\x86gina circled by he hears\r\nThe fair one\xe2\x80\x99s grief, and sees her falling tears.\r\n\r\nIn ninety sail, from Pylos\xe2\x80\x99 sandy coast,\r\nNestor the sage conducts his chosen host:\r\nFrom
