I. vers. 155, &c.\r\n\r\n40. The following argument of the Iliad, corrected in a few\r\nparticulars, is translated from Bitaube, and is, perhaps, the neatest\r\nsummary that has ever been drawn up:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA hero, injured by his general,\r\nand animated with a noble resentment, retires to his tent; and for a\r\nseason withdraws himself and his troops from the war. During this\r\ninterval, victory abandons the army, which for nine years has been\r\noccupied in a great enterprise, upon the successful termination of\r\nwhich the honour of their country depends. The general, at length\r\nopening his eyes to the fault which he had committed, deputes the\r\nprincipal officers of his army to the incensed hero, with commission to\r\nmake compensation for the injury, and to tender magnificent presents.\r\nThe hero, according to the proud obstinacy of his character, persists\r\nin his animosity; the army is again defeated, and is on the verge of\r\nentire destruction. This inexorable man has a friend; this friend weeps\r\nbefore him, and asks for the hero\xe2\x80\x99s arms, and for permission to go to\r\nthe war in his stead. The eloquence of friendship prevails more than\r\nthe intercession of the ambassadors or the gifts of the general. He\r\nlends his armour to his friend, but commands him not to engage with the\r\nchief of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s army, because he reserves to himself the honour of\r\nthat combat, and because he also fears for his friend\xe2\x80\x99s life. The\r\nprohibition is forgotten; the friend listens to nothing but his\r\ncourage; his corpse is brought back to the hero, and the hero\xe2\x80\x99s arms\r\nbecome the prize of the conqueror. Then the hero, given up to the most\r\nlively despair, prepares to fight; he receives from a divinity new\r\narmour, is reconciled with his general and, thirsting for glory and\r\nrevenge, enacts prodigies of valour, recovers the victory, slays the\r\nenemy\xe2\x80\x99s chief, honours his friend with superb funeral rites, and\r\nexercises a cruel vengeance on the body of his destroyer; but finally\r\nappeased by the tears and prayers of the father of the slain warrior,\r\nrestores to the old man the corpse of his son, which he buries with due\r\nsolemnities.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 177, sqq.\r\n\r\n41. Vultures: Pope is more accurate than the poet he translates, for\r\nHomer writes \xe2\x80\x9ca prey to dogs and to _all_ kinds of birds. But all kinds\r\nof birds are not carnivorous.\r\n\r\n42. \xe2\x80\x94_i.e._ during the whole time of their striving the will of Jove\r\nwas being gradually accomplished.\r\n\r\n43.\r\nCompare Milton\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost\xe2\x80\x9d i. 6\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSing, heavenly Muse, that on the secret top\r\nOf Horeb, or of Sinai, didst inspire\r\nThat shepherd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n44.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Latona\xe2\x80\x99s son: i.e._ Apollo.\r\n\r\n45.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_King of men:_ Agamemnon.\r\n\r\n46.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Brother kings:_ Menelaus and Agamemnon.\r\n\r\n47. \xe2\x80\x94_Smintheus_ an epithet taken from sminthos, the Phrygian name for\r\na _mouse,_ was applied to Apollo for having put an end to a plague of\r\nmice which had harassed that territory. Strabo, however, says, that\r\nwhen the Teucri were migrating from Crete, they were told by an oracle\r\nto settle in that place, where they should not be attacked by the\r\noriginal inhabitants of the land, and that, having halted for the\r\nnight, a number of field-mice came and gnawed away the leathern straps\r\nof their baggage, and thongs of their armour. In fulfilment of the\r\noracle, they settled on the spot, and raised a temple to Sminthean\r\nApollo. Grote, \xe2\x80\x9cHistory of Greece,\xe2\x80\x9d i. p. 68, remarks that the \xe2\x80\x9cworship\r\nof Sminthean Apollo, in various parts of the Troad and its neighboring\r\nterritory, dates before the earliest period of Aeolian colonization.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n48. \xe2\x80\x94_Cilla,_ a town of Troas near Thebe, so called from Cillus, a\r\nsister of Hippodamia, slain by OEnomaus.\r\n\r\n49. A mistake. It should be,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf e\xe2\x80\x99er I roofed thy graceful fane,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nfor the custom of decorating temples with garlands was of later date.\r\n\r\n50. \xe2\x80\x94_Bent was his bow_ \xe2\x80\x9cThe Apollo of Homer, it must be borne in mind,\r\nis a different character from the deity of the same name in the later\r\nclassical pantheon. Throughout both poems, all deaths from unforeseen\r\nor invisible causes, the ravages of pestilence, the fate of the young\r\nchild or promising adult, cut off in the germ of infancy or flower of\r\nyouth, of the old man dropping peacefully into the grave, or of the\r\nreckless sinner suddenly checked in his career of crime, are ascribed\r\nto the arrows of Apollo or Diana. The oracular functions of the god\r\nrose naturally out of the above fundamental attributes, for who could\r\nmore appropriately impart to mortals what little foreknowledge Fate\r\npermitted of her decrees than the agent of her most awful\r\ndispensations? The close union of the arts of prophecy and song\r\nexplains his additional office of god of music, while the arrows with\r\nwhich he and his sister were armed, symbols of sudden death in every\r\nage, no less naturally procured him that of god of archery. Of any\r\nconnection between Apollo and the Sun, whatever may have existed in the\r\nmore esoteric doctrine of the Greek sanctuaries, there is no trace in\r\neither Iliad or Odyssey.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, \xe2\x80\x9cHistory of Greek Literature,\xe2\x80\x9d vol. i.\r\np. 478, sq.\r\n\r\n51. It has frequently been observed, that most pestilences begin with\r\nanimals, and that Homer had this fact in mind.\r\n\r\n52. \xe2\x80\x94_Convened to council._ The public assembly in the heroic times is\r\nwell characterized by Grote, vol. ii. p 92. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is an assembly for\r\ntalk. Communication and discussion to a certain extent by the chiefs in\r\nperson, of the people as listeners and sympathizers\xe2\x80\x94often for\r\neloquence, and sometimes for quarrel\xe2\x80\x94but here its ostensible purposes\r\nend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n53. The Myrmidons dwelt on the southern borders of Thessaly, and took\r\ntheir origin from Myrmido, son of Jupiter and Eurymedusa. It is\r\nfancifully supposed that the name was derived from myrmaex, an _ant,_\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbecause they imitated the diligence of the ants, and like them were\r\nindefatigable, continually employed in cultivating the earth; the\r\nchange from ants to men is founded merely on the equivocation of their\r\nname, which resembles that of the ant: they bore a further resemblance\r\nto these little animals, in that instead of inhabiting towns or\r\nvillages, at first they commonly resided in the open fields, having no\r\nother retreats but dens and the cavities of trees, until Ithacus\r\nbrought them together, and settled them in more secure and comfortable\r\nhabitations.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Anthon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLempriere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n57. His mother, Thetis, the daughter of Nereus and Doris, who was\r\ncourted by Neptune and Jupiter. It has been observed that the annual procession of the sacred ship\r\nso often represented on Egyptian monuments, and the return of the deity\r\nfrom Ethiopia after some days\xe2\x80\x99 absence, serves to show the Ethiopian\r\norigin of Thebes, and of the worship of Jupiter Ammon. \xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d says\r\nHeeren, after quoting a passage from Diodorus about the holy ship,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat this procession is represented in one of the great sculptured\r\nreliefs on the temple of Karnak. The sacred ship of Ammon is on the\r\nshore with its whole equipment, and is towed along by another boat. It\r\nis therefore on its voyage. This must have been one of the most\r\ncelebrated festivals, since, even according to the interpretation of\r\nantiquity, Homer alludes to it when he speaks of Jupiter\xe2\x80\x99s visit to the\r\nEthiopians, and his twelve days\xe2\x80\x99 absence.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Long, \xe2\x80\x9cEgyptian Antiquities\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nvol. 1 p. 96. The occasion on which Vulcan incurred Jove\xe2\x80\x99s displeasure was\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94After Hercules, had taken and pillaged Troy, Juno raised a storm,\r\nwhich drove him to the island of Cos, having previously cast Jove into\r\na sleep, to prevent him aiding his son. This sentiment used to be a popular one with some of the greatest\r\ntyrants, who abused it into a pretext for unlimited usurpation of\r\npower. Dion, Caligula, and Domitian were particularly fond of it, and,\r\nin an extended form, we find the maxim propounded by Creon in the\r\nAntigone of Sophocles. See some important remarks of Heeren, \xe2\x80\x9cAncient\r\nGreece,\xe2\x80\x9d ch. vi. p. 105.\r\n\r\n87. It may be remarked, that the character of Thersites, revolting and\r\ncontemptible as it is, serves admirably to develop the disposition of\r\nUlysses in a new light, in which mere cunning is less prominent. Of the\r\ngradual and individual development of Homer\xe2\x80\x99s heroes, Schlegel well\r\nobserves, \xe2\x80\x9cIn bas-relief the figures are usually in profile, and in the\r\nepos all are characterized in the simplest manner in relief; they are\r\nnot grouped together, but follow one another; so Homer\xe2\x80\x99s heroes\r\nadvance, one by one, in succession before us. It has been remarked that\r\nthe _Iliad_ is not definitively closed, but that we are left to suppose\r\nsomething both to precede and to follow it. The bas-relief is equally\r\nwithout limit, and may be continued _ad infinitum,_ either from before\r\nor behind, on which account the ancients preferred for it such subjects\r\nas admitted of an indefinite extension, sacrificial processions,\r\ndances, and lines of combatants, and hence they also exhibit\r\nbas-reliefs on curved surfaces, such as vases, or the frieze of a\r\nrotunda, where, by the curvature, the two ends are withdrawn from our\r\nsight, and where, while we advance, one object appears as another\r\ndisappears. Reading Homer is very much like such a circuit; the present\r\nobject alone arresting our attention, we lose sight of what precedes,\r\nand do not concern ourselves about what is to follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDramatic\r\nLiterature,\xe2\x80\x9d p. 75.\r\n\r\n88. \xe2\x80\x9cThere cannot be a clearer indication than this description \xe2\x80\x94so\r\ngraphic in the original poem\xe2\x80\x94of the true character of the Homeric\r\nagora. The multitude who compose it are listening and acquiescent, not\r\noften hesitating, and never refractory to the chief. The fate which\r\nawaits a presumptuous critic, even where his virulent reproaches are\r\nsubstantially well-founded, is plainly set forth in the treatment of\r\nThersites; while the unpopularity of such a character is attested even\r\nmore by the excessive pains which Homer takes to heap upon him\r\nrepulsive personal deformities, than by the chastisement of Odysseus he\r\nis lame, bald, crook-backed, of misshapen head, and squinting\r\nvision.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote, vol. i. p. 97.\r\n\r\n89. According to Pausanias, both the sprig and the remains of the tree\r\nwere exhibited in his time. The tragedians, Lucretius and others,\r\nadopted a different fable to account for the stoppage at Aulis, and\r\nseem to have found the sacrifice of Iphigena better suited to form the\r\nsubject of a tragedy. Compare Dryden\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\x86neid,\xe2\x80\x9d vol. iii. sqq.\r\n\r\n90. \xe2\x80\x94_Full of his god, i.e.,_ Apollo, filled with the prophetic spirit.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_The_ god\xe2\x80\x9d would be more simple and emphatic.\r\n\r\n91. Those critics who have maintained that the \xe2\x80\x9cCatalogue of Ships\xe2\x80\x9d is\r\nan interpolation, should have paid more attention to these lines, which\r\nform a most natural introduction to their enumeration.\r\n\r\n92. The following observation will be useful to Homeric readers:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticular animals were, at a later time, consecrated to particular\r\ndeities. To Jupiter, Ceres, Juno, Apollo, and Bacchus victims of\r\nadvanced age might be offered. An ox of five years old was considered\r\nespecially acceptable to Jupiter. A black bull, a ram, or a boar pig,\r\nwere offerings for Neptune. A heifer, or a sheep, for Minerva. To Ceres\r\na sow was sacrificed, as an enemy to corn. The goat to Bacchus, because\r\nhe fed on vines. Diana was propitiated with a stag; and to Venus the\r\ndove was consecrated. The infernal and evil deities were to be appeased\r\nwith black victims. The most acceptable of all sacrifices was the\r\nheifer of a year old, which had never borne the yoke. It was to be\r\nperfect in every limb, healthy, and without blemish.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cElgin Marbles,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nvol. i. p. 78.\r\n\r\n93. \xe2\x80\x94_Idomeneus,_ son of Deucalion, was king of Crete. Having vowed,\r\nduring a tempest, on his return from Troy, to sacrifice to Neptune the\r\nfirst creature that should present itself to his eye on the Cretan\r\nshore, his son fell a victim to his rash vow.\r\n\r\n94. \xe2\x80\x94_Tydeus\xe2\x80\x99 son, i.e._ Diomed.\r\n\r\n95. That is, Ajax, the son of Oileus, a Locrian. He must be\r\ndistinguished from the other, who was king of Salamis.\r\n\r\n96. A great deal of nonsense has been written to account for the word\r\n_unbid,_ in this line. Even Plato, \xe2\x80\x9cSympos.\xe2\x80\x9d p. 315, has found some\r\ncurious meaning in what, to us, appears to need no explanation. Was\r\nthere any _heroic_ rule of etiquette which prevented one brother-king\r\nvisiting another without a formal invitation?\r\n\r\n97. Fresh water fowl, especially swans, were found in great numbers\r\nabout the Asian Marsh, a fenny tract of country in Lydia, formed by the\r\nriver Cayster, near its mouth. See Virgil, \xe2\x80\x9cGeorgics,\xe2\x80\x9d vol. i. 383, sq.\r\n\r\n98. \xe2\x80\x94_Scamander,_ or Scamandros, was a river of Troas, rising,\r\naccording to Strabo, on the highest part of Mount Ida, in the same hill\r\nwith the Granicus and the OEdipus, and falling into the sea at Sigaeum;\r\neverything tends to identify it with Mendere, as Wood, Rennell, and\r\nothers maintain; the Mendere is 40 miles long, 300 feet broad, deep in\r\nthe time of flood, nearly dry in the summer. Dr. Clarke successfully\r\ncombats the opinion of those who make the Scamander to have arisen from\r\nthe springs of Bounabarshy, and traces the source of the river to the\r\nhighest mountain in the chain of Ida, now Kusdaghy; receives the Simois\r\nin its course; towards its mouth it is very muddy, and flows through\r\nmarshes. Between the Scamander and Simois, Homer\xe2\x80\x99s Troy is supposed to\r\nhave stood: this river, according to Homer, was called Xanthus by the\r\ngods, Scamander by men. The waters of the Scamander had the singular\r\nproperty of giving a beautiful colour to the hair or wool of such\r\nanimals as bathed in them; hence the three goddesses, Minerva, Juno,\r\nand Venus, bathed there before they appeared before Paris to obtain the\r\ngolden apple: the name Xanthus, \xe2\x80\x9cyellow,\xe2\x80\x9d was given to the Scamander,\r\nfrom the peculiar colour of its waters, still applicable to the\r\nMendere, the yellow colour of whose waters attracts the attention of\r\ntravellers.\r\n\r\n99. It should be \xe2\x80\x9chis _chest_ like Neptune.\xe2\x80\x9d The torso of Neptune, in\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cElgin Marbles,\xe2\x80\x9d No. 103, (vol. ii. p. 26,) is remarkable for its\r\nbreadth and massiveness of development.\r\n\r\n100.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay first, for heav\xe2\x80\x99n hides nothing from thy view.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d i. 27.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMa di\xe2\x80\x99 tu, Musa, come i primi danni\r\nMandassero a Cristiani, e di quai parti:\r\nTu \xe2\x80\x99l sai; ma di tant\xe2\x80\x99 opra a noi si lunge\r\nDebil aura di fama appena giunge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGier. Lib.\xe2\x80\x9d iv. 19.\r\n\r\n101. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Catalogue is, perhaps, the portion of the poem in favour of\r\nwhich a claim to separate authorship has been most plausibly urged.\r\nAlthough the example of Homer has since rendered some such formal\r\nenumeration of the forces engaged, a common practice in epic poems\r\ndescriptive of great warlike adventures, still so minute a statistical\r\ndetail can neither be considered as imperatively required, nor perhaps\r\nsuch as would, in ordinary cases, suggest itself to the mind of a poet.\r\nYet there is scarcely any portion of the Iliad where both historical\r\nand internal evidence are more clearly in favour of a connection from\r\nthe remotest period, with the remainder of the work. The composition of\r\nthe Catalogue, whensoever it may have taken place, necessarily presumes\r\nits author\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance with a previously existing Iliad. It were\r\nimpossible otherwise to account for the harmony observable in the\r\nrecurrence of so vast a number of proper names, most of them\r\nhistorically unimportant, and not a few altogether fictitious: or of so\r\nmany geographical and genealogical details as are condensed in these\r\nfew hundred lines, and incidentally scattered over the thousands which\r\nfollow: equally inexplicable were the pointed allusions occurring in\r\nthis episode to events narrated in the previous and subsequent text,\r\nseveral of which could hardly be of traditional notoriety, but through\r\nthe medium of the Iliad.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, \xe2\x80\x9cLanguage and Literature of Greece,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nvol. i. p. 263.\r\n\r\n102. \xe2\x80\x94_Twice Sixty:_ \xe2\x80\x9cThucydides observes that the Boeotian vessels,\r\nwhich carried one hundred and twenty men each, were probably meant to\r\nbe the largest in the fleet, and those of Philoctetes, carrying fifty\r\neach, the smallest. The average would be eighty-five, and Thucydides\r\nsupposes the troops to have rowed and navigated themselves; and that\r\nvery few, besides the chiefs, went as mere passengers or landsmen. In\r\nshort, we have in the Homeric descriptions the complete picture of an\r\nIndian or African war canoe, many of which are considerably larger than\r\nthe largest scale assigned to those of the Greeks. If the total number\r\nof the Greek ships be taken at twelve hundred, according to Thucydides,\r\nalthough in point of fact there are only eleven hundred and eighty-six\r\nin the Catalogue, the amount of the army, upon the foregoing average,\r\nwill be about a hundred and two thousand men. The historian considers\r\nthis a small force as representing all Greece. Bryant, comparing it\r\nwith the allied army at Platae, thinks it so large as to prove the\r\nentire falsehood of the whole story; and his reasonings and\r\ncalculations are, for their curiosity, well worth a careful\r\nperusal.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 211, sq.\r\n\r\n103. The mention of Corinth is an anachronism, as that city was called\r\nEphyre before its capture by the Dorians. But Velleius, vol. i. p. 3,\r\nwell observes, that the poet would naturally speak of various towns and\r\ncities by the names by which they were known in his own time.\r\n\r\n104.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdam, the goodliest man of men since born,\r\nHis sons, the fairest of her daughters Eve.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d iv. 323.\r\n\r\n105. \xe2\x80\x94_\xc3\x86setes\xe2\x80\x99 tomb._ Monuments were often built on the sea-coast, and\r\nof a considerable height, so as to serve as watch-towers or land marks.\r\nSee my notes to my prose translations of the \xe2\x80\x9cOdyssey,\xe2\x80\x9d ii. p. 21, or\r\non Eur. \xe2\x80\x9cAlcest.\xe2\x80\x9d vol. i. p. 240.\r\n\r\n106. \xe2\x80\x94_Zeleia,_ another name for Lycia. Dysparis, i.e. unlucky, ill fated, Paris. This alludes to the\r\nevils which resulted from his having been brought up, despite the omens\r\nwhich attended his birth.\r\n\r\n112. The following scene, in which Homer has contrived to introduce so\r\nbrilliant a sketch of the Grecian warriors, has been imitated by\r\nEuripides, who in his \xe2\x80\x9cPhoenissae\xe2\x80\x9d represents Antigone surveying the\r\nopposing champions from a high tower, while the paedagogus describes\r\ntheir insignia and details their histories.\r\n\r\n113. \xe2\x80\x94_No wonder,_ &c. Zeuxis, the celebrated artist, is said to have\r\nappended these lines to his picture of Helen, as a motto. Valer Max.\r\niii. 7.\r\n\r\n114. The early epic was largely occupied with the exploits and\r\nsufferings of women, or heroines, the wives and daughters of the\r\nGrecian heroes. A nation of courageous, hardy, indefatigable women,\r\ndwelling apart from men, permitting only a short temporary intercourse,\r\nfor the purpose of renovating their numbers, burning out their right\r\nbreast with a view of enabling themselves to draw the bow freely; this\r\nwas at once a general type, stimulating to the fancy of the poet, and a\r\ntheme eminently popular with his hearers. We find these warlike females\r\nconstantly reappearing in the ancient poems, and universally accepted\r\nas past realities in the Iliad. When Priam wishes to illustrate\r\nemphatically the most numerous host in which he ever found himself\r\nincluded, he tells us that it was assembled in Phrygia, on the banks of\r\nthe Sangarius, for the purpose of resisting the formidable Amazons.\r\nWhen Bellerophon is to be employed in a deadly and perilous\r\nundertaking, by those who prudently wished to procure his death, he is\r\ndespatched against the Amazons.\xe2\x80\x94Grote, vol. i p. 289.\r\n\r\n115. \xe2\x80\x94_Antenor,_ like \xc3\x86neas, had always been favourable to the\r\nrestoration of Helen. Liv 1. 2.\r\n\r\n116.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis lab\xe2\x80\x99ring heart with sudden rapture seized\r\nHe paus\xe2\x80\x99d, and on the ground in silence gazed.\r\nUnskill\xe2\x80\x99d and uninspired he seems to stand,\r\nNor lifts the eye, nor graceful moves the hand:\r\nThen, while the chiefs in still attention hung,\r\nPours the full tide of eloquence along;\r\nWhile from his lips the melting torrent flows,\r\nSoft as the fleeces of descending snows.\r\nNow stronger notes engage the listening crowd,\r\nLouder the accents rise, and yet more loud,\r\nLike thunders rolling from a distant cloud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTryphiodorus,\xe2\x80\x9d 148, 99.\r\n\r\n117. Their medical\r\nrenown was further prolonged in the subsequent poem of Arktinus, the\r\nIliou Persis, wherein the one was represented as unrivalled in surgical\r\noperations, the other as sagacious in detecting and appreciating morbid\r\nsymptoms. It was Podaleirius who first noticed the glaring eyes and\r\ndisturbed deportment which preceded the suicide of Ajax.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGalen appears uncertain whether Asklepius (as well as Dionysus) was\r\noriginally a god, or whether he was first a man and then became\r\nafterwards a god; but Apollodorus professed to fix the exact date of\r\nhis apotheosis. Throughout all the historical ages the descendants of\r\nAsklepius were numerous and widely diffused. The many families or\r\ngentes, called Asklepiads, who devoted themselves to the study and\r\npractice of medicine, and who principally dwelt near the temples of\r\nAsklepius, whither sick and suffering men came to obtain relief\xe2\x80\x94all\r\nrecognized the god not merely as the object of their common worship,\r\nbut also as their actual progenitor.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote vol. i. p. 248.\r\n\r\n133.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe plant she bruises with a stone, and stands\r\nTempering the juice between her ivory hands\r\nThis o\xe2\x80\x99er her breast she sheds with sovereign art\r\nAnd bathes with gentle touch the wounded part\r\nThe wound such virtue from the juice derives,\r\nAt once the blood is stanch\xe2\x80\x99d, the youth revives.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrlando Furioso,\xe2\x80\x9d book 1.\r\n\r\n134.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Well might I wish._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould heav\xe2\x80\x99n (said he) my strength and youth recall,\r\nSuch as I was beneath Praeneste\xe2\x80\x99s wall\xe2\x80\x94\r\nThen when I made the foremost foes retire,\r\nAnd set whole heaps of conquer\xe2\x80\x99d shields on fire;\r\nWhen Herilus in single fight I slew,\r\nWhom with three lives Feronia did endue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, viii. 742.\r\n\r\n135. \xe2\x80\x94_Sthenelus,_ a son of Capaneus, one of the Epigoni. He was one of\r\nthe suitors of Helen, and is said to have been one of those who entered\r\nTroy inside the wooden horse.\r\n\r\n136. \xe2\x80\x94_Forwarn\xe2\x80\x99d the horrors._ The same portent has already been\r\nmentioned. To this day, modern nations are not wholly free from this\r\nsuperstition.\r\n\r\n137. \xe2\x80\x94_Sevenfold city,_ Boeotian Thebes, which had seven gates.\r\n\r\n138.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_As when the winds._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus, when a black-brow\xe2\x80\x99d gust begins to rise,\r\nWhite foam at first on the curl\xe2\x80\x99d ocean fries;\r\nThen roars the main, the billows mount the skies,\r\nTill, by the fury of the storm full blown,\r\nThe muddy billow o\xe2\x80\x99er the clouds is thrown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, vii. 736.\r\n\r\n139.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStood\r\nLike Teneriffe or Atlas unremoved;\r\nHis stature reach\xe2\x80\x99d the sky.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d iv. 986.\r\n\r\n140.\r\nThe Abantes seem to have been of Thracian origin.\r\n\r\n141. I may, once for all, remark that Homer is most anatomically\r\ncorrect as to the parts of the body in which a wound would be\r\nimmediately mortal.\r\n\r\n142.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_\xc3\x86nus,_ a fountain almost proverbial for its coldness.\r\n\r\n143.\r\nCompare Tasso, Gier. Lib., xx. 7:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNuovo favor del cielo in lui niluce\r\nE \xe2\x80\x99l fa grande, et angusto oltre il costume.\r\nGl\xe2\x80\x99 empie d\xe2\x80\x99 honor la faccia, e vi riduce\r\nDi giovinezza il bel purpureo lume.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n144.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr deluges, descending on the plains,\r\nSweep o\xe2\x80\x99er the yellow year, destroy the pains\r\nOf lab\xe2\x80\x99ring oxen, and the peasant\xe2\x80\x99s gains;\r\nUproot the forest oaks, and bear away\r\nFlocks, folds, and trees, an undistinguish\xe2\x80\x99d prey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil ii. 408.\r\n\r\n145.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_From mortal mists._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut to nobler sights\r\nMichael from Adam\xe2\x80\x99s eyes the film removed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d xi. 411.\r\n\r\n146.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_The race of those._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pair of coursers, born of heav\xe2\x80\x99nly breed,\r\nWho from their nostrils breathed ethereal fire;\r\nWhom Circe stole from her celestial sire,\r\nBy substituting mares produced on earth,\r\nWhose wombs conceived a more than mortal birth.\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, vii. 386, sqq.\r\n\r\n147.\r\nThe belief in the existence of men of larger stature in earlier times,\r\nis by no means confined to Homer.\r\n\r\n148.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Such stream, i.e._ the _ichor,_ or blood of the gods.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA stream of nect\xe2\x80\x99rous humour issuing flow\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nSanguine, such as celestial spirits may bleed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d vi. 339.\r\n\r\n149.\r\nThis was during the wars with the Titans.\r\n\r\n150.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Amphitryon\xe2\x80\x99s son,_ Hercules, born to Jove by Alcmena, the wife of Amphitryon.\r\n\r\n151. \xe2\x80\x94_\xc3\x86giale_ daughter of Adrastus. The Cyclic poets (See Anthon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nLempriere, _s. v._) assert Venus incited her to infidelity, in revenge\r\nfor the wound she had received from her husband.\r\n\r\n152. \xe2\x80\x94_Pherae,_ a town of Pelasgiotis, in Thessaly.\r\n\r\n153. \xe2\x80\x94_Tlepolemus,_ son of Hercules and Astyochia. Having left his\r\nnative country, Argos, in consequence of the accidental murder of\r\nLiscymnius, he was commanded by an oracle to retire to Rhodes. Here he\r\nwas chosen king, and accompanied the Trojan expedition. After his\r\ndeath, certain games were instituted at Rhodes in his honour, the\r\nvictors being rewarded with crowns of poplar.\r\n\r\n154. These heroes\xe2\x80\x99 names have since passed into a kind of proverb,\r\ndesignating the _oi polloi_ or mob.\r\n\r\n155.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Spontaneous open._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVeil\xe2\x80\x99d with his gorgeous wings, upspringing light\r\nFlew through the midst of heaven; th\xe2\x80\x99 angelic quires,\r\nOn each hand parting, to his speed gave way\r\nThrough all th\xe2\x80\x99 empyreal road; till at the gate\r\nOf heaven arrived, the gate self-open\xe2\x80\x99d wide,\r\nOn golden hinges turning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d v. 250.\r\n\r\n156.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill Morn,\r\nWaked by the circling Hours, with rosy hand\r\nUnbarr\xe2\x80\x99d the gates of light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d vi, 2.\r\n\r\n157. \xe2\x80\x94_Far as a shepherd._ \xe2\x80\x9cWith what majesty and pomp does Homer exalt\r\nhis deities! He here measures the leap of the horses by the extent of\r\nthe world. And who is there, that, considering the exceeding greatness\r\nof the space would not with reason cry out that \xe2\x80\x98If the steeds of the\r\ndeity were to take a second leap, the world would want room for\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Longinus, Section 8.\r\n\r\n158. \xe2\x80\x9cNo trumpets, or any other instruments of sound, are used in the\r\nHomeric action itself; but the trumpet was known, and is introduced for\r\nthe purpose of illustration as employed in war. Hence arose the value\r\nof a loud voice in a commander; Stentor was an indispensable officer...\r\nIn the early Saracen campaigns frequent mention is made of the service\r\nrendered by men of uncommonly strong voices; the battle of Honain was\r\nrestored by the shouts and menaces of Abbas, the uncle of Mohammed,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n&c.\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 213.\r\n\r\n159.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLong had the wav\xe2\x80\x99ring god the war delay\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nWhile Greece and Troy alternate own\xe2\x80\x99d his aid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTryphiodorus,\xe2\x80\x9d vi. 761, sq.\r\n\r\n160. \xe2\x80\x94_Paeon_ seems to have been to the gods, what Podaleirius and\r\nMachaon were to the Grecian heroes.\r\n\r\n161. \xe2\x80\x94_Arisbe,_ a colony of the Mitylenaeans in Troas.\r\n\r\n162. \xe2\x80\x94_Pedasus,_ a town near Pylos.\r\n\r\n163. \xe2\x80\x94_Rich heaps of brass._ \xe2\x80\x9cThe halls of Alkinous and Menelaus\r\nglitter with gold, copper, and electrum; while large stocks of yet\r\nunemployed metal\xe2\x80\x94gold, copper, and iron are stored up in the\r\ntreasure-chamber of Odysseus and other chiefs. Coined money is unknown\r\nin the Homeric age\xe2\x80\x94the trade carried on being one of barter. In\r\nreference also to the metals, it deserves to be remarked, that the\r\nHomeric descriptions universally suppose copper, and not iron, to be\r\nemployed for arms, both offensive and defensive. By what process the\r\ncopper was tempered and hardened, so as to serve the purpose of the\r\nwarrior, we do not know; but the use of iron for these objects belongs\r\nto a later age.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote, vol. ii. p. 142.\r\n\r\n164. \xe2\x80\x94_Oh impotent,_ &c. \xe2\x80\x9cIn battle, quarter seems never to have been\r\ngiven, except with a view to the ransom of the prisoner. Agamemnon\r\nreproaches Menelaus with unmanly softness, when he is on the point of\r\nsparing a fallen enemy, and himself puts the suppliant to the\r\nsword.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall, vol. i. p. 181\r\n\r\n165.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ruthless steel, impatient of delay,\r\nForbade the sire to linger out the day.\r\nIt struck the bending father to the earth,\r\nAnd cropt the wailing infant at the birth.\r\nCan innocents the rage of parties know,\r\nAnd they who ne\xe2\x80\x99er offended find a foe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRowe\xe2\x80\x99s Lucan, bk. ii.\r\n\r\n166.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeantime the Trojan dames, oppress\xe2\x80\x99d with woe,\r\nTo Pallas\xe2\x80\x99 fane in long procession go,\r\nIn hopes to reconcile their heav\xe2\x80\x99nly foe:\r\nThey weep; they beat their breasts; they rend their hair,\r\nAnd rich embroider\xe2\x80\x99d vests for presents bear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, i. 670\r\n\r\n167. The manner in which this episode is introduced, is well\r\nillustrated by the following remarks of Mure, vol. i. p.298: \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\npoet\xe2\x80\x99s method of introducing his episode, also, illustrates in a\r\ncurious manner his tact in the dramatic department of his art. Where,\r\nfor example, one or more heroes are despatched on some commission, to\r\nbe executed at a certain distance of time or place, the fulfilment of\r\nthis task is not, as a general rule, immediately described. A certain\r\ninterval is allowed them for reaching the appointed scene of action,\r\nwhich interval is dramatised, as it were, either by a temporary\r\ncontinuation of the previous narrative, or by fixing attention for a\r\nwhile on some new transaction, at the close of which the further\r\naccount of the mission is resumed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n168. \xe2\x80\x94_With tablets sealed._ These probably were only devices of a\r\nhieroglyphical character. Whether writing was known in the Homeric\r\ntimes is utterly uncertain. See Grote, vol ii. p. 192, sqq.\r\n\r\n169. \xe2\x80\x94_Solymaean crew,_ a people of Lycia.\r\n\r\n170. From this \xe2\x80\x9cmelancholy madness\xe2\x80\x9d of Bellerophon, hypochondria\r\nreceived the name of \xe2\x80\x9cMorbus Bellerophonteus.\xe2\x80\x9d See my notes in my prose\r\ntranslation, p. 112. The \xe2\x80\x9cAleian field,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._ \xe2\x80\x9cthe plain of\r\nwandering,\xe2\x80\x9d was situated between the rivers Pyramus and Pinarus, in\r\nCilicia.\r\n\r\n171. \xe2\x80\x94_His own, of gold._ This bad bargain has passed into a common\r\nproverb. See Aulus Gellius, ii, 23.\r\n\r\n172.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Scaean, i e._ left hand.\r\n\r\n173.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_In fifty chambers._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fifty nuptial beds, (such hopes had he,\r\nSo large a promise of a progeny,)\r\nThe ports of plated gold, and hung with spoils.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, ii.658\r\n\r\n174. \xe2\x80\x94_O would kind earth,_ &c. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is apparently a sudden, irregular\r\nburst of popular indignation to which Hector alludes, when he regrets\r\nthat the Trojans had not spirit enough to cover Paris with a mantle of\r\nstones. This, however, was also one of the ordinary formal modes of\r\npunishment for great public offences. It may have been originally\r\nconnected with the same feeling\xe2\x80\x94the desire of avoiding the pollution of\r\nbloodshed\xe2\x80\x94which seems to have suggested the practice of burying\r\nprisoners alive, with a scantling of food by their side. Though Homer\r\nmakes no mention of this horrible usage, the example of the Roman\r\nVestals affords reasons for believing that, in ascribing it to the\r\nheroic ages, Sophocles followed an authentic tradition.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGreece, vol. i. p. 171, sq.\r\n\r\n175. \xe2\x80\x94_Paris\xe2\x80\x99 lofty dome._ \xe2\x80\x9cWith respect to the private dwellings,\r\nwhich are oftenest described, the poet\xe2\x80\x99s language barely enables us to\r\nform a general notion of their ordinary plan, and affords no conception\r\nof the style which prevailed in them or of their effect on the eye. It\r\nseems indeed probable, from the manner in which he dwells on their\r\nmetallic ornaments that the higher beauty of proportion was but little\r\nrequired or understood, and it is, perhaps, strength and convenience,\r\nrather than elegance, that he means to commend, in speaking of the fair\r\nhouse which Paris had built for himself with the aid of the most\r\nskilful masons of Troy.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall\xe2\x80\x99s Greece, vol. i. p. 231.\r\n\r\n176.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_The wanton courser._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome destrier, che da le regie stalle\r\nOve a l\xe2\x80\x99usa de l\xe2\x80\x99arme si riserba,\r\nFugge, e libero al fiu per largo calle\r\nVa tragl\xe2\x80\x99 armenti, o al fiume usato, o a l\xe2\x80\x99herba.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGier, Lib. ix. 75.\r\n\r\n177. \xe2\x80\x94_Casque._ The original word is stephanae, about the meaning of\r\nwhich there is some little doubt. Some take it for a different kind of\r\ncap or helmet, others for the rim, others for the cone, of the helmet.\r\n\r\n178.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Athenian maid:_ Minerva.\r\n\r\n179.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Celadon,_ a river of Elis.\r\n\r\n180. \xe2\x80\x94_Oileus, i.e._ Ajax, the son of Oileus, in contradistinction to\r\nAjax, son of Telamon.\r\n\r\n181. \xe2\x80\x94_In the general\xe2\x80\x99s helm._ It was customary to put the lots into a\r\nhelmet, in which they were well shaken up; each man then took his\r\nchoice.\r\n\r\n182. \xe2\x80\x94_God of Thrace._ Mars, or Mavors, according to his Thracian\r\nepithet. Hence \xe2\x80\x9cMavortia Moenia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n183.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Grimly he smiled._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd death\r\nGrinn\xe2\x80\x99d horribly a ghastly smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d ii. 845.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere Mavors stands\r\nGrinning with ghastly feature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Carey\xe2\x80\x99s Dante: Hell, v.\r\n\r\n184.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSete o guerrieri, incomincio Pindoro,\r\nCon pari honor di pari ambo possenti,\r\nDunque cessi la pugna, e non sian rotte\r\nLe ragioni, e \xe2\x80\x99l riposo, e de la notte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Gier. Lib. vi. 51.\r\n\r\n185. It was an ancient style of compliment to give a larger portion of\r\nfood to the conqueror, or person to whom respect was to be shown. See\r\nVirg. \xc3\x86n. viii. 181. Thus Benjamin was honoured with a \xe2\x80\x9cdouble\r\nportion.\xe2\x80\x9d Gen. xliii. 34.\r\n\r\n186. \xe2\x80\x94_Embattled walls._ \xe2\x80\x9cAnother essential basis of mechanical unity\r\nin the poem is the construction of the rampart. This takes place in the\r\nseventh book. The reason ascribed for the glaring improbability that\r\nthe Greeks should have left their camp and fleet unfortified during\r\nnine years, in the midst of a hostile country, is a purely poetical\r\none: \xe2\x80\x98So long as Achilles fought, the terror of his name sufficed to\r\nkeep every foe at a distance.\xe2\x80\x99 The disasters consequent on his\r\nsecession first led to the necessity of other means of protection.\r\nAccordingly, in the battles previous to the eighth book, no allusion\r\noccurs to a rampart; in all those which follow it forms a prominent\r\nfeature. Here, then, in the anomaly as in the propriety of the Iliad,\r\nthe destiny of Achilles, or rather this peculiar crisis of it, forms\r\nthe pervading bond of connexion to the whole poem.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, vol. i., p.\r\n257.\r\n\r\n187.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_What cause of fear,_ &c.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeest thou not this? Or do we fear in vain\r\nThy boasted thunders, and thy thoughtless reign?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, iv. 304.\r\n\r\n188. \xe2\x80\x94_In exchange._ These lines are referred to by Theophilus, the\r\nRoman lawyer, iii. tit. xxiii. Section 1, as exhibiting the most\r\nancient mention of barter.\r\n\r\n189. \xe2\x80\x9cA similar bond of connexion, in the military details of the\r\nnarrative, is the decree issued by Jupiter, at the commencement of the\r\neighth book, against any further interference of the gods in the\r\nbattles. In the opening of the twentieth book this interdict is\r\nwithdrawn. During the twelve intermediate books it is kept steadily in\r\nview. No interposition takes place but on the part of the specially\r\nauthorised agents of Jove, or on that of one or two contumacious\r\ndeities, described as boldly setting his commands at defiance, but\r\nchecked and reprimanded for their disobedience; while the other divine\r\nwarriors, who in the previous and subsequent cantos are so active in\r\nsupport of their favourite heroes, repeatedly allude to the supreme\r\nedict as the cause of their present inactivity.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, vol. i. p 257.\r\nSee however, Muller, \xe2\x80\x9cGreek Literature,\xe2\x80\x9d ch. v. Section 6, and Grote,\r\nvol. ii. p. 252.\r\n\r\n190.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs far removed from God and light of heaven,\r\nAs from the centre thrice to th\xe2\x80\x99 utmost pole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cE quanto e da le stelle al basso inferno,\r\nTanto e piu in su de la stellata spera\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Gier. Lib. i. 7.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome of the epithets which Homer applies to the heavens seem to imply\r\nthat he considered it as a solid vault of metal. But it is not\r\nnecessary to construe these epithets so literally, nor to draw any such\r\ninference from his description of Atlas, who holds the lofty pillars\r\nwhich keep earth and heaven asunder. Yet it would seem, from the manner\r\nin which the height of heaven is compared with the depth of Tartarus,\r\nthat the region of light was thought to have certain bounds. The summit\r\nof the Thessalian Olympus was regarded as the highest point on the\r\nearth, and it is not always carefully distinguished from the aerian\r\nregions above The idea of a seat of the gods\xe2\x80\x94perhaps derived from a\r\nmore ancient tradition, in which it was not attached to any\r\ngeographical site\xe2\x80\x94seems to be indistinctly blended in the poet\xe2\x80\x99s mind\r\nwith that of the real mountain.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall\xe2\x80\x99s Greece, vol. i. p. 217,\r\nsq.\r\n\r\n191.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow lately heav\xe2\x80\x99n, earth, another world\r\nHung e\xe2\x80\x99er my realm, link\xe2\x80\x99d in a golden chain\r\nTo that side heav\xe2\x80\x99n.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d ii. 1004.\r\n\r\n192.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_His golden scales._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJove now, sole arbiter of peace and war,\r\nHeld forth the fatal balance from afar:\r\nEach host he weighs; by turns they both prevail,\r\nTill Troy descending fix\xe2\x80\x99d the doubtful scale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, v 687, sqq.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTh\xe2\x80\x99 Eternal, to prevent such horrid fray,\r\nHung forth in heav\xe2\x80\x99n his golden scales,\r\nWherein all things created first he weighed;\r\nThe pendulous round earth, with balanced air\r\nIn counterpoise; now ponders all events,\r\nBattles and realms. In these he puts two weights,\r\nThe sequel each of parting and of fight:\r\nThe latter quick up flew, and kick\xe2\x80\x99d the beam.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d iv. 496.\r\n\r\n193.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_And now,_ &c.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now all heaven\r\nHad gone to wrack, with ruin overspread;\r\nHad not th\xe2\x80\x99 Almighty Father, where he sits\r\n... foreseen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d vi. 669.\r\n\r\n194. \xe2\x80\x94_Gerenian Nestor._ The epithet _Gerenian_ either refers to the\r\nname of a place in which Nestor was educated, or merely signifies\r\nhonoured, revered. See Schol. Venet. in II. B. 336; Strabo, viii. p.\r\n340.\r\n\r\n195. \xe2\x80\x94_\xc3\x86gae, Helice._ Both these towns were conspicuous for their\r\nworship of Neptune.\r\n\r\n196.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_As full blown,_ &c.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIl suo Lesbia quasi bel fior succiso,\r\nE in atto si gentil languir tremanti\r\nGl\xe2\x80\x99 occhi, e cader siu \xe2\x80\x99l tergo il collo mira.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGier. Lib. ix. 85.\r\n\r\n197.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Ungrateful,_ because the cause in which they were engaged was\r\nunjust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStruck by the lab\xe2\x80\x99ring priests\xe2\x80\x99 uplifted hands\r\nThe victims fall: to heav\xe2\x80\x99n they make their pray\xe2\x80\x99r,\r\nThe curling vapours load the ambient air.\r\nBut vain their toil: the pow\xe2\x80\x99rs who rule the skies\r\nAverse beheld the ungrateful sacrifice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, vi. 527, sqq.\r\n\r\n198.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs when about the silver moon, when aire is free from winde,\r\nAnd stars shine cleare, to whose sweet beams high prospects on the brows\r\nOf all steepe hills and pinnacles thrust up themselves for shows,\r\nAnd even the lowly valleys joy to glitter in their sight;\r\nWhen the unmeasured firmament bursts to disclose her light,\r\nAnd all the signs in heaven are seene, that glad the shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChapman.\r\n\r\n199. This flight of the Greeks, according to Buttmann, Lexil. p. 358,\r\nwas not a supernatural flight caused by the gods, but \xe2\x80\x9ca great and\r\ngeneral one, caused by Hector and the Trojans, but with the approval of\r\nJove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n200. Grote, vol. ii. p. 91, after noticing the modest calmness and\r\nrespect with which Nestor addresses Agamemnon, observes, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Homeric\r\nCouncil is a purely consultative body, assembled not with any power of\r\nperemptorily arresting mischievous resolves of the king, but solely for\r\nhis information and guidance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n201. In the heroic times, it is not unfrequent for the king to receive\r\npresents to purchase freedom from his wrath, or immunity from his\r\nexactions. Such gifts gradually became regular, and formed the income\r\nof the German, (Tacit. Germ. Section 15) Persian, (Herodot. iii.89),\r\nand other kings. So, too, in the middle ages, \xe2\x80\x98The feudal aids are the\r\nbeginning of taxation, of which they for a long time answered the\r\npurpose.\xe2\x80\x99 (Hallam, Middle Ages, ch. x. pt. 1, p. 189) This fact frees\r\nAchilles from the apparent charge of sordidness. Plato, however, (De\r\nRep. vi. 4), says, \xe2\x80\x9cWe cannot commend Phoenix, the tutor of Achilles,\r\nas if he spoke correctly, when counselling him to accept of presents\r\nand assist the Greeks, but, without presents, not to desist from his\r\nwrath, nor again, should we commend Achilles himself, or approve of his\r\nbeing so covetous as to receive presents from Agamemnon,\xe2\x80\x9d &c.\r\n\r\n202. It may be observed, that, brief as is the mention of Briseis in\r\nthe Iliad, and small the part she plays\xe2\x80\x94what little is said is\r\npre-eminently calculated to enhance her fitness to be the bride of\r\nAchilles. Purity, and retiring delicacy, are features well contrasted\r\nwith the rough, but tender disposition of the hero.\r\n\r\n203. \xe2\x80\x94_Laodice._ Iphianassa, or Iphigenia, is not mentioned by Homer,\r\namong the daughters of Agamemnon.\r\n\r\n204. \xe2\x80\x9cAgamemnon, when he offers to transfer to Achilles seven towns\r\ninhabited by wealthy husbandmen, who would enrich their lord by\r\npresents and tribute, seems likewise to assume rather a property in\r\nthem, than an authority over them. And the same thing may be intimated\r\nwhen it is said that Peleus bestowed a great people, the Dolopes of\r\nPhthia, on Phoenix.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall\xe2\x80\x99s Greece, vol. i Section 6, p. 162,\r\nnote.\r\n\r\n205. \xe2\x80\x94_Pray in deep silence._ Rather: \xe2\x80\x9cuse well-omened words;\xe2\x80\x9d or, as\r\nKennedy has explained it, \xe2\x80\x9cAbstain from expressions unsuitable to the\r\nsolemnity of the occasion, which, by offending the god, might defeat\r\nthe object of their supplications.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n206. \xe2\x80\x94_Purest hands._ This is one of the most ancient superstitions\r\nrespecting prayer, and one founded as much in nature as in tradition.\r\n\r\n207. It must be recollected, that the war at Troy was not a settled\r\nsiege, and that many of the chieftains busied themselves in piratical\r\nexpeditions about its neighborhood. Such a one was that of which\r\nAchilles now speaks. From the following verses, it is evident that\r\nfruits of these maraudings went to the common support of the\r\nexpedition, and not to the successful plunderer.\r\n\r\n208. \xe2\x80\x94_Pythia,_ the capital of Achilles\xe2\x80\x99 Thessalian domains.\r\n\r\n209. \xe2\x80\x94_Orchomenian town._ The topography of Orchomenus, in Boeotia,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csituated,\xe2\x80\x9d as it was, \xe2\x80\x9con the northern bank of the lake \xc3\x86pais, which\r\nreceives not only the river Cephisus from the valleys of Phocis, but\r\nalso other rivers from Parnassus and Helicon\xe2\x80\x9d (Grote, vol. p. 181), was\r\na sufficient reason for its prosperity and decay. \xe2\x80\x9cAs long as the\r\nchannels of these waters were diligently watched and kept clear, a\r\nlarge portion of the lake was in the condition of alluvial land,\r\npre-eminently rich and fertile. But when the channels came to be either\r\nneglected, or designedly choked up by an enemy, the water accumulated\r\nin such a degree as to occupy the soil of more than one ancient islet,\r\nand to occasion the change of the site of Orchomenus itself from the\r\nplain to the declivity of Mount Hyphanteion.\xe2\x80\x9d (Ibid.)\r\n\r\n210. The phrase \xe2\x80\x9chundred gates,\xe2\x80\x9d &c., seems to be merely expressive of\r\na great number. See notes to my prose translation, p. 162.\r\n\r\n211. Compare the following pretty lines of Quintus Calaber (Dyce\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nSelect Translations, p 88).\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMany gifts he gave, and o\xe2\x80\x99er\r\nDolopia bade me rule; thee in his arms\r\nHe brought an infant, on my bosom laid\r\nThe precious charge, and anxiously enjoin\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThat I should rear thee as my own with all\r\nA parent\xe2\x80\x99s love. I fail\xe2\x80\x99d not in my trust\r\nAnd oft, while round my neck thy hands were lock\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nFrom thy sweet lips the half articulate sound\r\nOf Father came; and oft, as children use,\r\nMewling and puking didst thou drench my tunic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis description,\xe2\x80\x9d observes my learned friend (notes, p. 121) \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\ntaken from the passage of Homer, II ix, in translating which, Pope,\r\nwith that squeamish, artificial taste, which distinguished the age of\r\nAnne, omits the natural (and, let me add, affecting) circumstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the wine\r\nHeld to thy lips, and many a time in fits\r\nOf infant frowardness the purple juice\r\nRejecting thou hast deluged all my vest,\r\n\r\nAnd fill\xe2\x80\x99d my bosom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Cowper.\r\n\r\n212. \xe2\x80\x94_Where Calydon._ For a good sketch of the story of Meleager, too\r\nlong to be inserted here, see Grote, vol. i. p. 195, sqq.; and for the\r\nauthorities, see my notes to the prose translation, p. 166.\r\n\r\n213. \xe2\x80\x9c_Gifts can conquer_\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94It is well observed by Bishop Thirlwall,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreece,\xe2\x80\x9d vol. i. p, 180, that the law of honour among the Greeks did\r\nnot compel them to treasure up in their memory the offensive language\r\nwhich might be addressed to them by a passionate adversary, nor to\r\nconceive that it left a stain which could only be washed away by blood.\r\nEven for real and deep injuries they were commonly willing to accept a\r\npecuniary compensation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n214. \xe2\x80\x9cThe boon of sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Milton\r\n\r\n215.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll else of nature\xe2\x80\x99s common gift partake:\r\nUnhappy Dido was alone awake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Dryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, iv. 767.\r\n\r\n216.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_The king of Crete:_ Idomeneus.\r\n\r\n217. \xe2\x80\x94_Soft wool within, i e._ a kind of woollen stuffing, pressed in\r\nbetween the straps, to protect the head, and make the helmet fit close.\r\n\r\n218. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the circumstances of this action\xe2\x80\x94the night, Rhesus buried in\r\na profound sleep, and Diomede with the sword in his hand hanging over\r\nthe head of that prince\xe2\x80\x94furnished Homer with the idea of this fiction,\r\nwhich represents Rhesus lying fast asleep, and, as it were, beholding\r\nhis enemy in a dream, plunging the sword into his bosom. This image is\r\nvery natural; for a man in his condition awakes no farther than to see\r\nconfusedly what environs him, and to think it not a reality but a\r\ndream.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Pope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s one did laugh in his sleep, and one cry\xe2\x80\x99d murder;\r\nThey wak\xe2\x80\x99d each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Macbeth._\r\n\r\n219.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAurora now had left her saffron bed,\r\nAnd beams of early light the heavens o\xe2\x80\x99erspread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, iv. 639\r\n\r\n220. \xe2\x80\x94_Red drops of blood._ \xe2\x80\x9cThis phenomenon, if a mere fruit of the\r\npoet\xe2\x80\x99s imagination, might seem arbitrary or far-fetched. 239, also speaks of the independence of these people,\r\nwhich he regards as the result of their poverty and uprightness. Some\r\nauthors have regarded the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cHippomolgian,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._ \xe2\x80\x9cmilking their\r\nmares,\xe2\x80\x9d as an epithet applicable to numerous tribes, since the oldest\r\nof the Samatian nomads made their mares\xe2\x80\x99 milk one of their chief\r\narticles of diet. The epithet abion or abion, in this passage, has\r\noccasioned much discussion. It may mean, according as we read it,\r\neither \xe2\x80\x9clong-lived,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbowless,\xe2\x80\x9d the latter epithet indicating that\r\nthey did not depend upon archery for subsistence.\r\n\r\n230.\r\nCompare Chapman\xe2\x80\x99s quaint, bold verses:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as a round piece of a rocke, which with a winter\xe2\x80\x99s flood\r\nIs from his top torn, when a shoure poured from a bursten cloud,\r\nHath broke the naturall band it had within the roughftey rock,\r\nFlies jumping all adourne the woods, resounding everie shocke,\r\nAnd on, uncheckt, it headlong leaps till in a plaine it stay,\r\nAnd then (tho\xe2\x80\x99 never so impelled), it stirs not any way:\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSo Hector,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n231. This book forms a most agreeable interruption to The continuous\r\nround of battles, which occupy the latter part of the Iliad. Lib. xvi. 25\r\n\r\n234.\r\nCompare the description of the dwelling of Sleep in Orlando Furioso,\r\nbk. vi.\r\n\r\n235.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwice seven, the charming daughters of the main\xe2\x80\x94\r\nAround my person wait, and bear my train:\r\nSucceed my wish, and second my design,\r\nThe fairest, Deiopeia, shall be thine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, \xc3\x86n. i. 107, seq.\r\n\r\n236. \xe2\x80\x94_And Minos._ \xe2\x80\x9cBy Homer, Minos is described as the son of Jupiter,\r\nand of the daughter of Phoenix, whom all succeeding authors name\r\nEuropa; and he is thus carried back into the remotest period of Cretan\r\nantiquity known to the poet, apparently as a native hero, Illustrious\r\nenough for a divine parentage, and too ancient to allow his descent to\r\nbe traced to any other source. But in a genealogy recorded by later\r\nwriters, he is likewise the adopted son of Asterius, as descendant of\r\nDorus, the son of Helen, and is thus connected with a colony said to\r\nhave been led into Creta by Tentamus, or Tectamus, son of Dorus, who is\r\nrelated either to have crossed over from Thessaly, or to have embarked\r\nat Malea after having led his followers by land into\r\nLaconia.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall, p. 136, seq.\r\n\r\n237. Milton has emulated this passage, in describing the couch of our\r\nfirst parents:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnderneath the violet,\r\nCrocus, and hyacinth with rich inlay,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Broider\xe2\x80\x99d the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d iv. 700.\r\n\r\n238.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_He lies protected,_\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForthwith on all sides to his aid was run\r\nBy angels many and strong, who interpos\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nDefence, while others bore him on their shields\r\nBack to his chariot, where it stood retir\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nFrom off the files of war; there they him laid,\r\nGnashing for anguish, and despite, and shame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d vi. 335, seq.\r\n\r\n239.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_The brazen dome._ See the note on Bk. viii. Page 142.\r\n\r\n240. \xe2\x80\x94_For, by the gods! who flies._ Observe the bold ellipsis of \xe2\x80\x9che\r\ncries,\xe2\x80\x9d and the transition from the direct to the oblique construction.\r\nSo in Milton:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus at their shady lodge arriv\xe2\x80\x99d, both stood,\r\nBoth turn\xe2\x80\x99d, and under open sky ador\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThe God that made both sky, air, earth, and heaven,\r\nWhich they beheld, the moon\xe2\x80\x99s resplendent globe,\r\nAnd starry pole.\xe2\x80\x94Thou also mad\xe2\x80\x99st the night,\r\nMaker omnipotent, and thou the day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilton, \xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d Book iv.\r\n\r\n241.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_So some tall rock._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut like a rock unmov\xe2\x80\x99d, a rock that braves\r\nThe raging tempest, and the rising waves\xe2\x80\x94\r\nPropp\xe2\x80\x99d on himself he stands: his solid sides\r\nWash off the sea-weeds, and the sounding tides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, vii. 809.\r\n\r\n242. Protesilaus was the first Greek who fell, slain by Hector, as he\r\nleaped from the vessel to the Trojan shore. He was buried on the\r\nChersonese, near the city of Plagusa. Hygin Fab. ciii. Tzetz. on\r\nLycophr. 245, 528. There is a most elegant tribute to his memory in the\r\nPreface to the Heroica of Philostratus.\r\n\r\n243. \xe2\x80\x94_His best beloved._ The following elegant remarks of Thirlwall\r\n(Greece, vol. i, p. 176 seq.) well illustrate the character of the\r\nfriendship subsisting between these two heroes\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the noblest and most amiable sides of the Greek character, is\r\nthe readiness with which it lent itself to construct intimate and\r\ndurable friendships, and this is a feature no less prominent in the\r\nearliest than in later times. It was indeed connected with the\r\ncomparatively low estimation in which female society was held; but the\r\ndevotedness and constancy with which these attachments were maintained,\r\nwas not the less admirable and engaging. The heroic companions whom we\r\nfind celebrated partly by Homer and partly in traditions which, if not\r\nof equal antiquity, were grounded on the same feeling, seem to have but\r\none heart and soul, with scarcely a wish or object apart, and only to\r\nlive as they are always ready to die for one another. It is true that\r\nthe relation between them is not always one of perfect equality; but\r\nthis is a circumstance which, while it often adds a peculiar charm to\r\nthe poetical description, detracts little from the dignity of the idea\r\nwhich it presents. Such were the friendships of Hercules and Iolaus, of\r\nTheseus and Pirithous, of Orestes and Pylades; and though These may owe\r\nthe greater part of their fame to the later epic or even dramatic\r\npoetry, the moral groundwork undoubtedly subsisted in the period to\r\nwhich the traditions are referred. The argument of the Iliad mainly\r\nturns on the affection of Achilles for Patroclus, whose love for the\r\ngreater hero is only tempered by reverence for his higher birth and his\r\nunequalled prowess. But the mutual regard which united Idomeneus and\r\nMeriones, Diomedes and Sthenelus, though, as the persons themselves are\r\nless important, it is kept more in the back-ground, is manifestly\r\nviewed by the poet in the same light. The idea of a Greek hero seems\r\nnot to have been thought complete, without such a brother in arms by\r\nhis side.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Thirlwall, Greece, vol. i. p. 176, seq.\r\n\r\n244.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs hungry wolves with raging appetite,\r\nScour through the fields, ne\xe2\x80\x99er fear the stormy night\xe2\x80\x94\r\nTheir whelps at home expect the promised food,\r\nAnd long to temper their dry chaps in blood\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSo rush\xe2\x80\x99d we forth at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Dryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, ii. 479.\r\n\r\n245. \xe2\x80\x94_The destinies ordain._\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIn the mythology, also, of the Iliad,\r\npurely Pagan as it is, we discover one important truth unconsciously\r\ninvolved, which was almost entirely lost from view amidst the nearly\r\nequal scepticism and credulity of subsequent ages. Zeus or Jupiter is\r\npopularly to be taken as omnipotent. No distinct empire is assigned to\r\nfate or fortune; the will of the father of gods and men is absolute and\r\nuncontrollable. This seems to be the true character of the Homeric\r\ndeity, and it is very necessary that the student of Greek literature\r\nshould bear it constantly in mind. A strong instance in the Iliad\r\nitself to illustrate this position, is the passage where Jupiter\r\nlaments to Juno the approaching death of Sarpedon. \xe2\x80\x98Alas me!\xe2\x80\x99 says he\r\n\xe2\x80\x98since it is fated (moira) that Sarpedon, dearest to me of men, should\r\nbe slain by Patroclus, the son of Menoetius! Indeed, my heart is\r\ndivided within me while I ruminate it in my mind, whether having\r\nsnatched him up from out of the lamentable battle, I should not at once\r\nplace him alive in the fertile land of his own Lycia, or whether I\r\nshould now destroy him by the hands of the son of Menoetius!\xe2\x80\x99 To which\r\nJuno answers\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Dost thou mean to rescue from death a mortal man, long\r\nsince destined by fate (palai pepromenon)? You may do it\xe2\x80\x94but we, the\r\nrest of the gods, do not sanction it.\xe2\x80\x99 Here it is clear from both\r\nspeakers, that although Sarpedon is said to be fated to die, Jupiter\r\nmight still, if he pleased, save him, and place him entirely out of the\r\nreach of any such event, and further, in the alternative, that Jupiter\r\nhimself would destroy him by the hands of another.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 156.\r\nseq.\r\n\r\n246. \xe2\x80\x94_Thrice at the battlements._ \xe2\x80\x9cThe art military of the Homeric age\r\nis upon a level with the state of navigation just described, personal\r\nprowess decided every thing; the night attack and the ambuscade,\r\nalthough much esteemed, were never upon a large scale. The chiefs fight\r\nin advance, and enact almost as much as the knights of romance. The\r\nsiege of Troy was as little like a modern siege as a captain in the\r\nguards is like Achilles. There is no mention of a ditch or any other\r\nline or work round the town, and the wall itself was accessible without\r\na ladder. It was probably a vast mound of earth with a declivity\r\noutwards. Patroclus thrice mounts it in armour. The Trojans are in no\r\nrespects blockaded, and receive assistance from their allies to the\r\nvery end.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 212.\r\n\r\n247. \xe2\x80\x94_Ciconians._\xe2\x80\x94A people of Thrace, near the Hebrus.\r\n\r\n248.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_They wept._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFast by the manger stands the inactive steed,\r\nAnd, sunk in sorrow, hangs his languid head;\r\nHe stands, and careless of his golden grain,\r\nWeeps his associates and his master slain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, v. 18-24.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is heard upon the mountains now,\r\nBut pensive herds that for their master low,\r\nStraggling and comfortless about they rove,\r\nUnmindful of their pasture and their love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMoschus, id. 3, parodied, _ibid._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo close the pomp, \xc3\x86thon, the steed of state,\r\nIs led, the funeral of his lord to wait.\r\nStripp\xe2\x80\x99d of his trappings, with a sullen pace\r\nHe walks, and the big tears run rolling down his face.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, bk. ii\r\n\r\n249.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Some brawny bull._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike to a bull, that with impetuous spring\r\nDarts, at the moment when the fatal blow\r\nHath struck him, but unable to proceed\r\nPlunges on either side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Carey\xe2\x80\x99s Dante: Hell, c. xii.\r\n\r\n250. This is connected with the earlier part of last book, the regular\r\nnarrative being interrupted by the message of Antilochus and the\r\nlamentations of Achilles.\r\n\r\n251. \xe2\x80\x94_Far in the deep._ So Oceanus hears the lamentations of\r\nPrometheus, in the play of \xc3\x86schylus, and comes from the depths of the\r\nsea to comfort him.\r\n\r\n252.\r\nOpuntia, a city of Locris.\r\n\r\n253. Quintus Calaber, lib. v., has attempted to rival Homer in his\r\ndescription of the shield of the same hero. A few extracts from Mr.\r\nDyce\xe2\x80\x99s version (Select Translations, p. 104, seq.) may here be\r\nintroduced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the wide circle of the shield were seen\r\nRefulgent images of various forms,\r\nThe work of Vulcan; who had there described\r\nThe heaven, the ether, and the earth and sea,\r\nThe winds, the clouds, the moon, the sun, apart\r\nIn different stations; and you there might view\r\nThe stars that gem the still-revolving heaven,\r\nAnd, under them, the vast expanse of air,\r\nIn which, with outstretch\xe2\x80\x99d wings, the long-beak\xe2\x80\x99d bird\r\nWinnow\xe2\x80\x99d the gale, as if instinct with life.\r\nAround the shield the waves of ocean flow\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThe realms of Tethys, which unnumber\xe2\x80\x99d streams,\r\nIn azure mazes rolling o\xe2\x80\x99er the earth,\r\nSeem\xe2\x80\x99d to augment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n254. \xe2\x80\x94_On seats of stone._ \xe2\x80\x9cSeveral of the old northern Sagas represent\r\nthe old men assembled for the purpose of judging as sitting on great\r\nstones, in a circle called the Urtheilsring or gerichtsring\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 Grote,\r\nii. p. 100, note. On the independence of the judicial office in The\r\nheroic times, see Thirlwall\xe2\x80\x99s Greece, vol. i. p. 166.\r\n\r\n255.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Another part,_ &c.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here\r\nWere horrid wars depicted; grimly pale\r\nWere heroes lying with their slaughter\xe2\x80\x99d steeds\r\nUpon the ground incarnadin\xe2\x80\x99d with blood.\r\nStern stalked Bellona, smear\xe2\x80\x99d with reeking gore,\r\nThrough charging ranks; beside her Rout was seen,\r\nAnd Terror, Discord to the fatal strife\r\nInciting men, and Furies breathing flames:\r\nNor absent were the Fates, and the tall shape\r\nOf ghastly Death, round whom did Battles throng,\r\nTheir limbs distilling plenteous blood and sweat;\r\nAnd Gorgons, whose long locks were twisting snakes.\r\nThat shot their forky tongues incessant forth.\r\nSuch were the horrors of dire war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Dyce\xe2\x80\x99s Calaber.\r\n\r\n256.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_A field deep furrowed._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere was a corn field; reapers in a row,\r\nEach with a sharp-tooth\xe2\x80\x99d sickle in his hand,\r\nWork\xe2\x80\x99d busily, and, as the harvest fell,\r\nOthers were ready still to bind the sheaves:\r\nYoked to a wain that bore the corn away\r\nThe steers were moving; sturdy bullocks here\r\nThe plough were drawing, and the furrow\xe2\x80\x99d glebe\r\nWas black behind them, while with goading wand\r\nThe active youths impell\xe2\x80\x99d them. Here a feast\r\nWas graved: to the shrill pipe and ringing lyre\r\nA band of blooming virgins led the dance.\r\nAs if endued with life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Dyce\xe2\x80\x99s Calaber.\r\n\r\n257. Coleridge (Greek Classic Poets, p. 182, seq.) has diligently\r\ncompared this with the description of the shield of Hercules by Hesiod.\r\nHe remarks that, \xe2\x80\x9cwith two or three exceptions, the imagery differs in\r\nlittle more than the names and arrangements; and the difference of\r\narrangement in the Shield of Hercules is altogether for the worse. The\r\nnatural consecution of the Homeric images needs no exposition: it\r\nconstitutes in itself one of the beauties of the work. The Hesiodic\r\nimages are huddled together without connection or congruity: Mars and\r\nPallas are awkwardly introduced among the Centaurs and Lapithae;\xe2\x80\x94 but\r\nthe gap is wide indeed between them and Apollo with the Muses, waking\r\nthe echoes of Olympus to celestial harmonies; whence however, we are\r\nhurried back to Perseus, the Gorgons, and other images of war, over an\r\narm of the sea, in which the sporting dolphins, the fugitive fishes,\r\nand the fisherman on the shore with his casting net, are minutely\r\nrepresented. As to the Hesiodic images themselves, the leading remark\r\nis, that they catch at beauty by ornament, and at sublimity by\r\nexaggeration; and upon the untenable supposition of the genuineness of\r\nthis poem, there is this curious peculiarity, that, in the description\r\nof scenes of rustic peace, the superiority of Homer is decisive\xe2\x80\x94while\r\nin those of war and tumult it may be thought, perhaps, that the\r\nHesiodic poet has more than once the advantage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n258. \xe2\x80\x9cThis legend is one of the most pregnant and characteristic in the\r\nGrecian Mythology; it explains, according to the religious ideas\r\nfamiliar to the old epic poets, both the distinguishing attributes and\r\nthe endless toil and endurances of Heracles, the most renowned\r\nsubjugator of all the semi-divine personages worshipped by the\r\nHellenes,\xe2\x80\x94a being of irresistible force, and especially beloved by\r\nZeus, yet condemned constantly to labour for others and to obey the\r\ncommands of a worthless and cowardly persecutor. His recompense is\r\nreserved to the close of his career, when his afflicting trials are\r\nbrought to a close: he is then admitted to the godhead, and receives in\r\nmarriage Hebe.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote, vol. i. p. 128.\r\n\r\n259.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Ambrosia._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe blue-eyed maid,\r\nIn ev\xe2\x80\x99ry breast new vigour to infuse.\r\nBrings nectar temper\xe2\x80\x99d with ambrosial dews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, vi. 249.\r\n\r\n260. \xe2\x80\x9cHell is naked before him, and destruction hath no covering. He\r\nstretcheth out the north over the empty place, and hangeth the earth\r\nupon nothing. He bindeth up the waters in his thick clouds; and the\r\ncloud is not rent under them.\xe2\x80\x9d Job xxvi. 6-8.\r\n\r\n261.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwift from his throne the infernal monarch ran,\r\nAll pale and trembling, lest the race of man,\r\nSlain by Jove\xe2\x80\x99s wrath, and led by Hermes\xe2\x80\x99 rod,\r\nShould fill (a countless throng!) his dark abode.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, vi. 769, sqq.\r\n\r\n262. These words seem to imply the old belief, that the Fates might be\r\ndelayed, but never wholly set aside.\r\n\r\n263. It was anciently believed that it was dangerous, if not fatal, to\r\nbehold a deity. See Exod. xxxiii. 20; Judg. xiii. 22.\r\n\r\n264.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEre Ilium and the Trojan tow\xe2\x80\x99rs arose,\r\nIn humble vales they built their soft who\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOutstripp\xe2\x80\x99d the winds in speed upon the plain,\r\nFlew o\xe2\x80\x99er the field, nor hurt the bearded grain:\r\nShe swept the seas, and, as she skimm\xe2\x80\x99d along,\r\nHer flying feet unbathed on billows hung.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden, vii. 1100.\r\n\r\n266. \xe2\x80\x94_The future father._ \xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\x86neas and Antenor stand distinguished sight,\r\nSustain\xe2\x80\x99d the vanquish\xe2\x80\x99d, and secured his flight\xe2\x80\x94\r\nEven then secured him, when I sought with joy\r\nThe vow\xe2\x80\x99d destruction of ungrateful Troy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, v. 1058.\r\n\r\n268. \xe2\x80\x94_On Polydore._ Euripides, Virgil, and others, relate that\r\nPolydore was sent into Thrace, to the house of Polymestor, for\r\nprotection, being the youngest of Priam\xe2\x80\x99s sons, and that he was\r\ntreacherously murdered by his host for the sake of the treasure sent\r\nwith him.\r\n\r\n269. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the boldest excursion of Homer into this region of\r\npoetical fancy is the collision into which, in the twenty-first of the\r\nIliad, he has brought the river god Scamander, first with Achilles, and\r\nafterwards with Vulcan, when summoned by Juno to the hero\xe2\x80\x99s aid. The\r\noverwhelming fury of the stream finds the natural interpretation in the\r\ncharacter of the mountain torrents of Greece and Asia Minor. Their\r\nwide, shingly beds are in summer comparatively dry, so as to be easily\r\nforded by the foot passenger. But a thunder-shower in the mountains,\r\nunobserved perhaps by the traveller on the plain, may suddenly immerse\r\nhim in the flood of a mighty river. The rescue of Achilles by the fiery\r\narms of Vulcan scarcely admits of the same ready explanation from\r\nphysical causes. Yet the subsiding of the flood at the critical moment\r\nwhen the hero\xe2\x80\x99s destruction appeared imminent, might, by a slight\r\nextension of the figurative parallel, be ascribed to a god symbolic of\r\nthe influences opposed to all atmospheric moisture.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, vol. i. p.\r\n480, sq.\r\n\r\n270. Wood has observed, that \xe2\x80\x9cthe circumstance of a falling tree, which\r\nis described as reaching from one of its banks to the other, affords a\r\nvery just idea of the breadth of the Scamander.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n271. \xe2\x80\x94_Ignominious._ Drowning, as compared with a death in the field of\r\nbattle, was considered utterly disgraceful.\r\n\r\n272.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Beneath a caldron._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, when with crackling flames a caldron fries,\r\nThe bubbling waters from the bottom rise.\r\nAbove the brims they force their fiery way;\r\nBlack vapours climb aloft, and cloud the day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, vii. 644.\r\n\r\n273. \xe2\x80\x9cThis tale of the temporary servitude of particular gods, by order\r\nof Jove, as a punishment for misbehaviour, recurs not unfrequently\r\namong the incidents of the Mythical world.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote, vol. i. p. 156.\r\n\r\n274.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Not half so dreadful._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the other side,\r\nIncensed with indignation, Satan stood\r\nUnterrified, and like a comet burn\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThat fires the length of Ophiuchus huge\r\nIn the arctic sky, and from his horrid hair\r\nShakes pestilence and war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d xi. 708.\r\n\r\n275. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd thus his own undaunted mind explores.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d vi.\r\n113.\r\n\r\n276. Such was his fate. After chasing the Trojans into the town, he was\r\nslain by an arrow from the quiver of Paris, directed under the unerring\r\nauspices of Apollo. The greatest efforts were made by the Trojans to\r\npossess themselves of the body, which was however rescued and borne off\r\nto the Grecian camp by the valour of Ajax and Ulysses. Thetis stole\r\naway the body, just as the Greeks were about to burn it with funeral\r\nhonours, and conveyed it away to a renewed life of immortality in the\r\nisle of Leuke in the Euxine.\r\n\r\n279. \xe2\x80\x94_Astyanax,_ i.e. the _city-king_ or guardian.
