The height of the tomb or pile was a great proof of the dignity of\r\nthe deceased, and the honour in which he was held.\r\n\r\n289. On the prevalence of this cruel custom amongst the northern\r\nnations, see Mallet, p. 213.\r\n\r\n290. \xe2\x80\x94_And calls the spirit._ Such was the custom anciently, even at\r\nthe Roman funerals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHail, O ye holy manes! hail again,\r\nPaternal ashes, now revived in vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, v. 106.\r\n\r\n291. Virgil, by making the boaster vanquished, has drawn a better moral\r\nfrom this episode than Homer. The following lines deserve comparison:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe haughty Dares in the lists appears:\r\nWalking he strides, his head erected bears:\r\nHis nervous arms the weighty gauntlet wield,\r\nAnd loud applauses echo through the field.\r\n* * * *\r\nSuch Dares was, and such he strode along,\r\nAnd drew the wonder of the gazing throng\r\nHis brawny breast and ample chest he shows;\r\nHis lifted arms around his head he throws,\r\nAnd deals in whistling air his empty blows.\r\nHis match is sought, but, through the trembling band,\r\nNo one dares answer to the proud demand.\r\nPresuming of his force, with sparkling eyes,\r\nAlready he devours the promised prize.\r\n* * * *\r\nIf none my matchless valour dares oppose,\r\nHow long shall Dares wait his dastard foes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, v. 486, seq.\r\n\r\n292.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gauntlet-fight thus ended, from the shore\r\nHis faithful friends unhappy Dares bore:\r\nHis mouth and nostrils pour\xe2\x80\x99d a purple flood,\r\nAnd pounded teeth came rushing with his blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden\xe2\x80\x99s Virgil, v. 623.\r\n\r\n293. \xe2\x80\x9cTroilus is only once named in the Iliad; he was mentioned also in\r\nthe Cypriad but his youth, beauty, and untimely end made him an object\r\nof great interest with the subsequent poets.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Grote, i, p. 399.\r\n\r\n294. Milton has rivalled this passage describing the descent of\r\nGabriel, \xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost,\xe2\x80\x9d bk. v. 266, seq.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDown thither prone in flight\r\nHe speeds, and through the vast ethereal sky\r\nSails between worlds and worlds, with steady wing,\r\nNow on the polar winds, then with quick fan\r\nWinnows the buxom air. * * * *\r\n* * * *\r\nAt once on th\xe2\x80\x99 eastern cliff of Paradise\r\nHe lights, and to his proper shape returns\r\nA seraph wing\xe2\x80\x99d. * * * *\r\nLike Maia\xe2\x80\x99s son he stood,\r\nAnd shook his plumes, that heavenly fragrance fill\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThe circuit wide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVirgil, \xc3\x86n. iv. 350:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHermes obeys; with golden pinions binds\r\nHis flying feet, and mounts the western winds:\r\nAnd whether o\xe2\x80\x99er the seas or earth he flies,\r\nWith rapid force they bear him down the skies\r\nBut first he grasps within his awful hand\r\nThe mark of sovereign power, his magic wand;\r\nWith this he draws the ghost from hollow graves;\r\nWith this he drives them from the Stygian waves:\r\n* * * *\r\nThus arm\xe2\x80\x99d, the god begins his airy race,\r\nAnd drives the racking clouds along the liquid space.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDryden.\r\n\r\n295. In reference to the whole scene that follows, the remarks of\r\nColeridge are well worth reading:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a close study of life, and by a true and natural mode of expressing\r\neverything, Homer was enabled to venture upon the most peculiar and\r\ndifficult situations, and to extricate himself from them with the\r\ncompletest success. The whole scene between Achilles and Priam, when\r\nthe latter comes to the Greek camp for the purpose of redeeming the\r\nbody of Hector, is at once the most profoundly skilful, and yet the\r\nsimplest and most affecting passage in the Iliad. Quinctilian has taken\r\nnotice of the following speech of Priam, the rhetorical artifice of\r\nwhich is so transcendent, that if genius did not often, especially in\r\noratory, unconsciously fulfil the most subtle precepts of criticism, we\r\nmight be induced, on this account alone, to consider the last book of\r\nthe Iliad as what is called spurious, in other words, of later date\r\nthan the rest of the poem. Observe the exquisite taste of Priam in\r\noccupying the mind of Achilles, from the outset, with the image of his\r\nfather; in gradually introducing the parallel of his own situation;\r\nand, lastly, mentioning Hector\xe2\x80\x99s name when he perceives that the hero\r\nis softened, and then only in such a manner as to flatter the pride of\r\nthe conqueror. The ego d\xe2\x80\x99eleeinoteros per, and the apusato aecha\r\ngeronta, are not exactly like the tone of the earlier parts of the\r\nIliad. They are almost too fine and pathetic. The whole passage defies\r\ntranslation, for there is that about the Greek which has no name, but\r\nwhich is of so fine and ethereal a subtlety that it can only be felt in\r\nthe original, and is lost in an attempt to transfuse it into another\r\nlanguage.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Coleridge, p. 195.\r\n\r\n296. \xe2\x80\x9cAchilles\xe2\x80\x99 ferocious treatment of the corpse of Hector cannot but\r\noffend as referred to the modern standard of humanity. The heroic age,\r\nhowever, must be judged by its own moral laws. Retributive vengeance on\r\nthe dead, as well as the living, was a duty inculcated by the religion\r\nof those barbarous times which not only taught that evil inflicted on\r\nthe author of evil was a solace to the injured man; but made the\r\nwelfare of the soul after death dependent on the fate of the body from\r\nwhich it had separated. Hence a denial of the rites essential to the\r\nsoul\xe2\x80\x99s admission into the more favoured regions of the lower world was\r\na cruel punishment to the wanderer on the dreary shores of the infernal\r\nriver. The complaint of the ghost of Patroclus to Achilles, of but a\r\nbrief postponement of his own obsequies, shows how efficacious their\r\nrefusal to the remains of his destroyer must have been in satiating the\r\nthirst of revenge, which, even after death, was supposed to torment the\r\ndwellers in Hades. Hence before yielding up the body of Hector to\r\nPriam, Achilles asks pardon of Patroclus for even this partial cession\r\nof his just rights of retribution.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, vol. i. 289.\r\n\r\n297.\r\nSuch was the fate of Astyanax, when Troy was taken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, from the tow\xe2\x80\x99r by stern Ulysses thrown,\r\nAndromache bewail\xe2\x80\x99d her infant son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerrick\xe2\x80\x99s Tryphiodorus, v. 675.\r\n\r\n298. The following observations of Coleridge furnish a most gallant and\r\ninteresting view of Helen\xe2\x80\x99s character\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFew things are more interesting than to observe how the same hand that\r\nhas given us the fury and inconsistency of Achilles, gives us also the\r\nconsummate elegance and tenderness of Helen. She is through the Iliad a\r\ngenuine lady, graceful in motion and speech, noble in her associations,\r\nfull of remorse for a fault for which higher powers seem responsible,\r\nyet grateful and affectionate towards those with whom that fault had\r\ncommitted her. I have always thought the following speech in which\r\nHelen laments Hector, and hints at her own invidious and unprotected\r\nsituation in Troy, as almost the sweetest passage in the poem. It is\r\nanother striking instance of that refinement of feeling and softness of\r\ntone which so generally distinguish the last book of the Iliad from the\r\nrest.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Classic Poets, p. 198, seq.\r\n\r\n299. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd here we part with Achilles at the moment best calculated to\r\nexalt and purify our impression of his character. We had accompanied\r\nhim through the effervescence, undulations, and final subsidence of his\r\nstormy passions. We now leave him in repose and under the full\r\ninfluence of the more amiable affections, while our admiration of his\r\ngreat qualities is chastened by the reflection that, within a few short\r\ndays the mighty being in whom they were united was himself to be\r\nsuddenly cut off in the full vigour of their exercise.\r\n\r\nThe frequent and touching allusions, interspersed throughout the Iliad,\r\nto the speedy termination of its hero\xe2\x80\x99s course, and the moral on the\r\nvanity of human life which they indicate, are among the finest\r\nevidences of the spirit of ethic unity by which the whole framework of\r\nthe poem is united.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Mure, vol. i. p 201.\r\n\r\n300. Cowper says,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot take my leave of this noble poem without\r\nexpressing how much I am struck with the plain conclusion of it. It is\r\nlike the exit of a great man out of company, whom he has entertained\r\nmagnificently; neither pompous nor familiar; not contemptuous, yet\r\nwithout much ceremony.\xe2\x80\x9d Coleridge, p. 227, considers the termination of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParadise Lost\xe2\x80\x9d somewhat similar.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE ILIAD ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 6130-0.txt or 6130-0.zip *****\r\nThis and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n    https://www.gutenberg.org/6/1/3/6130/\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United\r\nStates without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
